SHARE Blotter, Sept. 16, 2016 Glenwood police are looking for information on a man seen on surveillance video stealing electronics from Walmart. By Staff Wednesday, September 14, 2016 Cops look for theft suspect The Glenwood Springs Police Department hopes someone can recognize a man caught on surveillance video who stole electronics from Walmart on Tuesday night. Police said the man entered the store, at 3010 Blake Ave., 20 minutes before midnight. They allege he selected a mobile hotspot device, cut the packaging open, and removed the device before leaving the store, making no attempt to pay. Anyone with information as to the person’s identity is asked to call police at 970-384-6500 or submit a crime tip online at glenwoodpolice.com/crime-tips.   According to the Grand Junction Police Department: ■ Thomas Valdez, 21, is accused of assault on Sept. 9. ■ Marcos Adan, 30, was cited on suspicion of assault on Sunday. ■ Zachary English, 21, was cited on suspicion of disorderly house on Sunday. ■ Florencio Gonzalez, 19, was cited on suspicion of shoplifting on Tuesday. ■ Manuel Pinal-Gomez, 25, is accused of third-degree assault, child abuse, violation of bond conditions, and domestic violence on Tuesday. ■ Someone removed a victim’s vehicle from the 2800 block of North Avenue on Tuesday. ■ Someone stole a wallet with cash at a business in the 2700 block of U.S. Highway 50 on Tuesday, causing a loss of more than $2,000. ■ Someone caused a loss of less than $300 when items of value were taken from a vehicle located near the 500 block of Rio Oso Lane on Sept. 8.   According to the Mesa County Sheriff’s Office: ■ Cory Shaine Davis, 31, an inmate at the Mesa County Jail, was cited on suspicion of third-degree assault on Aug. 13. ■ Kelli Strike, 34, is accused of criminal impersonation and drug charges on Sept. 4. ■ Someone caused approximately $1,830 in damage to a vehicle in the 3000 block of Bookcliff Avenue on Sept. 6. ■ Andrea Harris, 30, is accused of auto theft on Monday. ■ A theft from auto was reported in the 3100 block of Arrowhead Trail on Monday. ■ Someone removed $2,864 worth of property from the 3000 block of Lawson Avenue on Sept. 10.   According to the Montrose County Sheriff’s Office: ■ Jose E. Ramirez, 30, Olathe, is accused of possession of an explosive device on Wednesday. ■ Misty S, Kinas, 34, Montrose, is accused of violating a protection order on Wednesday. ■ Cody W. Charron, 40, is accused of violating a protection order on Tuesday. COMMENTS Commenting is not available in this channel entry. BuzzWorthy Online Videos Odd News Social Media Human Interest Aliens & UFOs Theories BuzzWorthy 2016-11-18 Marilyn Monroe ‘Happy Birthday, Mr. President’ Dress Sells For $4.81 Million BuzzWorthy 2016-11-17 Social Media’s #UNameItChallenge Goes Viral Before Thanksgiving, Gospel Star Shirley Caesar Responds BuzzWorthy 2016-11-17 Teacher Ruins Autistic Boy’s Role In School Play, Leaves Him Sobbing On Stage In Front Of Audience BuzzWorthy 2016-11-17 Flagstaff Police Officer Caught On Tape Punching Woman In The Face, Department Is Investigating [Video] SUBSCRIBE Full RSS Feed Latest News Feed Entertainment News Feed Tech Feed World News Gaming Feed Sports Feed Funny & Strange Feed Health Feed Lifestyle Feed BuzzWorthy Feed Never miss a story get the latest viral news to your inbox Delivered To Your INBOX Never miss a story get the latest viral news to your inbox Email Address Or follow us online Facebook Twitter Google-plus Rss Media Blackouts: The Biggest Story Of This Century Opinion 1.3k 0 0 September 16, 2016 Media Blackouts: The Biggest Story Of This Century Caitlin Johnstone The following article is entirely the opinion of Caitlin Johnstone and does not reflect the views of the Inquisitr. Mainstream media’s near-complete blackout on major stories and events is without a doubt the most interesting thing happening in the world today. Earlier today, WikiLeaks dropped a massive bombshell about the largest trade agreement ever made, which covers 52 countries and affects 80 percent of the economy in the U.S. and Europe, accounting for two-thirds of the global GDP. It will allow Wal-Mart economics to flourish on a global scale, forbidding the governments of participating nations from preferencing local businesses over foreign ones, and making it nearly impossible to stop those businesses from predatory pricing practices. In effect, there will be nothing stopping giant businesses from opening up shops on the corners of every neighborhood in any of the 52 participating nations, and using their wealth reserves to undercut the prices of all local businesses, forcing them to close and becoming the only business (and employer) of that type in the area. You know how every time a Wal-Mart opens in a new neighborhood it undercuts its competition and forces them to fold, offers new jobs at slave wages and then uses corporatist lobbying to protect itself from repercussions and shift the burden of the damage it does to the American taxpayer? It will be like that, only worldwide, with all businesses, including banks. You would be forgiven if you don’t know the name of the planet-altering trade deal I’m referring to, because you’ve never seen a news story on it. This would be the Trade in Service Agreement, or TiSA, also known as the TPP and TTIP’s secret brother. WikiLeaks revealed a major block of information about this agreement which will, without question, significantly alter the way humanity itself moves and behaves on this planet, and Wolf Blitzer’s dead-eyed face has nothing whatsoever to say about it. Why Do Six Companies Control 90% of the Media?: http://t.co/sh9aNtbMWu pic.twitter.com/NgeBt7H4xB — Adbusters (@Adbusters) September 2, 2015 Americans enjoy freedom of the press under the First Amendment of the Constitution because an informed populace is an essential ingredient in a healthy democracy, and citizens have understandably come to rely upon the press to provide that information. But time after time, story after story, important information has been getting swept under the rug by all the biggest news media providers in the country. The minority of Americans who are plugged into alternative news media have been witnessing a very different world unfold than those who get their news from CNN, Fox, or the New York Times. While we watched Bernie Sanders launch an unprecedented crowd-funded campaign to pack stadiums and win election battles he never should have been able to win, consumers of mainstream media were fed a constant diet of Donald Trump’s mouth farts. #SignsYoureABernieSupporter You & other @BernieSanders' supporters refuse MSM's #mediablackout to defeat him & us. pic.twitter.com/rirsyvnXL5 — KyleTaylorLucas (@KyleTaylorLucas) March 31, 2016 Tens of thousands of people were gathering for an unknown underdog, a man who even called himself that pariah term “democratic socialist” and who was calling for something as outrageous as a revolution, but that once-in-a-lifetime story went untold by the mass media. Only in Facebook groups could you see video of the moving scene of thousands of people from all walks of life lining up for blocks and blocks. Only through regular people’s updates and livestreams could you get the inside story of the voter suppression and voter culls, deliberate cutting of booths in a historically popular primary season and the long long lines it created, hundreds of stories of older, sicker, over-employed-but-underpaid people having to give up and leave the line before voting, dead people voting for Hillary, schools of mentally challenged people being bussed in to vote for Hillary, bosses giving their staff the day off as long as they voted for Hillary, dodgy machines, massively irregular exit polls and ex-presidents with bullhorns blocking the entrances to key polling booths for hours. I am so ready for a @BernieSanders revolution! #HIcaucus #FeelTheBern #BirdieSanders #MediaBlackout pic.twitter.com/QNb2DeFQR8 — Christie Sparrow (@sparrows1981) March 27, 2016 None of these stories were covered. Surely one of the biggest political uprisings in living memory was barely mentioned, and was mostly scorned by all the major news players, and as the season went on, a lot of the minor ones too. Alternative media outlets like The Onion were noticeably bought up by big-time Clinton donors, and their editorial immediately changed. It had the desired effect, too. A Harvard study confirmed that the media blackout alone fatally hindered Sanders’ momentum and lost him the election. In fact, if there was any coverage, it was to mock suggestions that the DNC were colluding against Sanders as “conspiracy theory.” Even when that conspiracy theory became conspiracy fact, there was no mea culpa from the media. In fact, they mocked people further by intimating that they had known all along it was rigged and somehow turned it around to make us look stupid again. We see what you did there. To mock people for suspecting what you secretly know is happening, and then mock them again by saying “Of course it happens” is double-dipping on the whole pompous mockery thing. You either knew, or you didn’t. The tag of “conspiracy theorist” is used to mollify anyone who doesn’t toe the corporate line. The assertions that Hillary might not be feeling so hot were shouted down as conspiracy theory and sexism and a Huffington Post writer even lost his job for pointing out the rumours about her health. Lost his job. For simply doing his actual job and reporting on what turned out to be the truth. Dr. Drew Pinksy was threatened and his show was axed days after suggesting that Hillary Clinton’s health care was a concern. Not even her health. Just the care she was getting. Is anyone else getting creeped out here? This is like an abusive gas lighting technique, but on a massive nation-wide scale. “You’re crazy! You’re insane! She’s fine! You’re a conspiracy nut!… Oh, she’s sick, but it’s nothing, she’s our gal, she’ll pull through, nothing to see here!” All in the space of a day. Yeah, that’s totally normal. Just this last week, a deluge of data has come from Guccifer 2.0 leaks, detailing proof of absolutely astounding government appointments, dizzyingly high-up jobs, including many positions of real national power like the FCC Chairman, auctioned off to the highest bidder. Obama was cheerily raking in the dough while selling off our most powerful public positions. This is possibly the most shocking revelation of Obama’s presidency, and the most damning indictment to come to light yet on the ever-growing history of deep corporate corruption among the Democrats, and do you think it made it to any of the leading newspapers? Nuh-uh. Not a peep. Not to mention the mercenaries setting their attack dogs on the Dakota Access Pipeline protestors. I mean that literally — there was no mention of it. Except of course by Democracy Now’s Amy Goodman, who got an arrest warrant for her efforts. Even Facebook is stopping protestors from sending out live streams. Look up any of these stories and there is a dearth of material on them. If you use Google, rather than Bing or Yahoo!, you will get even less. #MediaBlackout: Mercenaries Attack Thousands of #NativeAmericans. https://t.co/ywEozSznjG #NoDAPL #NativeLivesMatter pic.twitter.com/OOPGJXJJEr — النجم الملتهب (@kingk8888) September 6, 2016 What is this, Burma? Even they have given up censorship. And at least they used to give you the courtesy of selling the newspaper with the censored news blacked out. There are no black boxes in our newspapers hinting at what cannot be safely said or is not allowed to be known though. Just mockery where the news should be. [Featured Image by Shutterstock] Now Watch This: Val Chmerkovskiy Sued For $6 Million After Posting Insulting Meme Now Read This: Man’s Drone Catches Cheating Wife Of 18 Years: 9 Million YouTube Video Views, Update — What’s The Real Story? About Us  |  Advertise  |  Subscribe  |  Distribute  |  About The Publisher  |  Contact Friday, 11.18.2016, 10:14 AM (GMT-5) Home Community News Opinions In Our Opinion Other Voices International U.S.A Crime Art & Culture Sahtak More النسخة العربية The American spirit didn't die on Nov. 8   |   Local Arabs and Jews join forces against bigotry   |   Republicans urge minorities to give Trump a chance, despite intolerant advisors   |   Post Trump's election: A spike in racism and hate crimes   |   Newlyweds forced to purchase their stolen jewelry back from pawn shop   |   Sheikh who publicly supports Trump is a fraud   |   We accept the democratic process and prepare to push back   |   Among devastated Arabs and Muslims, Trump's victory is a call to organize   |   Historic win for Abdullah Hammoud sets stage for challenges in state House   |   Local races drive Arab Americans to the polls Advanced Search U.S.A Walmart, Coke apologize for 9/11-themed display at Florida store | Thursday, 09.15.2016, 08:15 PM PANAMA CITY, Florida — A Walmart spokesman said a 9/11-themed display at a Florida store was designed and created by Coca-Cola. A photo of the display at the Walmart in Panama City, Fla. was posted to Twitter by user @online_shawn and immediately sparked outrage among online commentators who objected to the use of the Sept. 11, 2001 attacks to sell Coke, as well as the arrangement of the Coke boxes to resemble the twin towers in front of an American flag. "We will never forget," reads a banner bearing the Coca-Cola and Walmart logos. Walmart spokesman Charles Crowson said the display was being removed following the online outcry. Crowson told the Orlando Weekly the display was pitched to Walmart by Coke, and the store approved it. "We hold this moment in our country's history in the highest regard, and there was nothing disrespectful intended by the display being assembled. It was removed from our Florida store Wednesday," Walmart said in a statement emailed to Mashable. Coca-Cola spokeswoman Kimberly Kuo said the display was misinterpreted. "This display was meant to honor local firefighters and to support their organization's upcoming event," she told CNBC. "We sincerely apologize that anyone was offended or misunderstood its intent and we have replaced the display."  (Votes: 0) Please enable JavaScript to view the comments powered by Disqus. H T Imam, adviser of political affairs to the prime minister, was present as the chief guest while former governor of Bangladesh Bank Dr Mohammed Farashuddin was present as one of the keynote speakers in the seminar. Print   Email   Font Resize Community News Upcoming Sterling, Logan County events --- Sept. 17 - Sept. 19 Posted:   09/17/2016 07:03:19 AM MDT Today, Sept. 17 Recycling Collection — 8 to 11 a.m., southeast corner of Walmart parking lot. Collection includes: Plastic #1, plastic #2 natural (milk cartons), plastic #2 colored (detergent bottles, shampoo, etc.) and both aluminum and tin cans. No glass. Sugar Beet Days — 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., Logan County Courthouse Square. Logan County Humane Society Pet Expo and Adoption Fair — 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., Johnson and Associates, 400 S. Division Ave. Information: Carol 970-522-3279. Narcotics Anonymous — 1:30 p.m., First Christian Church. Information: 970-520-1474. NJC 75th Anniversary 5k Water Run — 6:30 to 7:30 a.m. check in, 8 a.m. race, Cosmetology Building, 1102 Sidney Ave. Entre fee $20 for adults (age 12 and over), $10 for youth (ages 7-11), free for ages 6 and under. Registration forms available at Hays Student Center room 116. Information: 970-521-6658. Heritage Center Dance Group — 6:30 to 10 p.m., Joe Judd. Cost $7. Everyone is welcome. Northern Lights Narcotics Anonymous — 9 p.m., 1325 N. 7th St. Sunday, Sept. 18 Air Force Birthday Celebration — 11 a.m. to 1 p.m., Home Depot. Free lunch for all veterans. Advertisement Sugar Beet Days — 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., Logan County Courthouse Square. Zion Congregational Church Soup Kitchen — 11:30 a.m. to 1 p.m., 5th Street and Chestnut. Come to the back door and down the stairs. Free. Meals served to anyone who is hungry and in need of a hot meal. Movie Matinee — 4 p.m., 315 W. Railroad Ave., Iliff. Free popcorn. Monday, Sept. 19 SilverSneakers Yoga — 10 a.m., Heritage Center. Tai Chi — 11:30 a.m., Heritage Center. Cards and Pool, Pinochle — 1 p.m., Heritage Center. Body Sculpting and Tone Class — 5:15 to 6 p.m., Ayres Elementary. Cost is $5 per session. To sign up, call instruction and Wellness Specialist Angie Myers at 521-3226. Circle of Parents in Recovery Group — 5 to 6 p.m., 118 N. 2nd St. Free childcare is provided. No enrollment requirement, join at any time. Information: cleanslatemngr@frcsterling.org, 970-520-2939 or www.facebook.com/logancleanslate. RE-1 Valley School Board — 6 p.m., Hagen Administration Center. Logan County Child Care Association — 6:30 to 8:30 p.m., Trinity Lutheran Church, fellowship hall. Stephanie Weeder, 522-5942. Clean Slate Recovery Group — 6:30 to 7:30 p.m., 118 N. 2nd St. Open to anyone struggling with addiction. Information: Christie Orozco 970-526-6500, 970-520-2939 or csrecovery1028@gmail.com, Facebook or Twitter. Spunk and Spirit Christian Writers Group — 6:30 to 8 p.m., Life Fellowship in Fort Morgan. VoteWise — 6:30 p.m., The Joy Mission, 3rd and Maple St., Julesburg. Learn about government function, examine U.S. Constitution and how to exercise your rights as a voter. Everyone is welcome. (Through Nov. 7). TOPS: Take Off Pounds Sensibly — 7 p.m., VFW Hall, 803 Phelps St. Call 522-8396. Northern Lights Narcotics Anonymous — 7:30 p.m., 1325 N. 7th St. Military Family Support Group — 7:30 p.m., Family Resource Center. Come in back door. Bill, Denise Gaynor, 522-3794; or LuAnn Travis, 522-6356. READ MORE READ MORE READ MORE Share Aol.com Editors Sep 6th 2016 1:22PM Summer sales are coming to a close, and to some of us avid shoppers, that means we have one thing next on our radar: holiday shopping! Lucky for us, Wal-Mart just unveiled its annual list of the top holiday toys of 2016. The retailer polled hundreds of kids ages 18 months to 12 years to find out what items are topping their wish lists this year -- and while several newcomers made the rankings, classic names like Star Wars, Disney and Barbie still prove to be crowd favorites. Six of the 25 toys are exclusive to Wal-Mart. Says Anne Marie Kehoe, Vice President of Toys at Wal-Mart U.S., "We are confident our assortment hits the mark with kids of all ages - we have playsets, ridealongs, licensed merchandise even toys that fly." So what toys are kids asking from Santa this holiday season? AccuWeather.com Quick Look Change your current location » View Full Weather Report Search Search Search NJ.com Account Sign In Close Sign in to NJ.com You are signed in as Edit Public Profile Sign Out Subscribe Email newsletters The Star-Ledger The Times of Trenton The Jersey Journal South Jersey Times Hunterdon County Democrat Star Gazette comments 'Shoplifter' shot by cops in Walmart parking lot: mayor Print Email Michaelangelo Conte | The Jersey Journal By Michaelangelo Conte | The Jersey Journal The Jersey Journal Follow on Twitter on September 17, 2016 at 3:00 AM, updated September 17, 2016 at 9:25 AM comments A man suspected of shoplifting at the Walmart in Kearny yesterday morning was shot by a police officer when he drove his vehicle at the officer while trying to flee, the town's mayor said yesterday afternoon. The accused shoplifter, Ramon Martinez, 43, of Newark, and a second man, Diego C. Dosreis, age 28, also of Newark, have been charged, Hudson County Prosecutor Esther Suarez said. Martinez is charged with eluding, receiving stolen property and shoplifting. Dosreis has been charged with receiving stolen property, Prosecutor's Office spokesman Ray Worrall said. The Kearny police officer who shot Martinez was not injured, but he was evaluated at a local hospital, which is standard procedure when an officer fires his weapon, Kearny Mayor Al Santos said. The officer, who was not identified, is a veteran of the force, the mayor said. Martinez was struck in "an extremity," the Prosecutor's Office said, and he is in stable condition at a local hospital. Santos said the shooting appeared to be justified. "The suspect is believed to have been a fleeing shoplifter and he threatened the officer with his vehicle," Santos said. "The officer had to respond. He shot at the suspect because he was threatened by the suspect's vehicle as he tried to get away from the police officer trying to apprehend him." Santos said the officer fired multiple shots and at least one struck Martinez in the parking lot of the store on Harrison Avenue. The incident is being reviewed, as is customary, by the Hudson County Prosecutor's Office, which did not provide any further details on the incident. "When faced with an oncoming car, it seems to me it was an appropriate response," Santos said. "The incident is under review and if there are any questions, we will be looking at them." Santos credited his detectives for tracking down the shoplifter and his alleged accomplice. "The detectives who were able to apprehend the suspect, their police work was outstanding," Santos said. "The suspect had fled after the shooting in the parking lot and the Kearny Detective Squad, based on information they collected at scene, were able to apprehend him later in Newark. "It's important that the suspect was arrested ... (as) it is also a deterrent because you know there is an effective response and police officers will be on the scene promptly and an arrest will be made." News Sports Entertainment Life Opinion Obituaries ePaper Cars Jobs Homes Classifieds log in Site Archive 2 changes approved for site plans for new Dunkin' Donuts in Brooklyn Friday Sep 16, 2016 at 6:36 PM Sep 16, 2016 at 6:36 PM Francesca Kefalas For The Bulletin BROOKLYN — It's almost time to make the doughnuts. The small plaza planned for the former site of St. John Lutheran Church across from Wal-Mart has been back to the Planning and Zoning Commission several times over the summer, but its owner says he is now ready to build. “It would have been easier to do everything all at once, but the timing didn’t work out that way,” said Norm Thibeault, of Killingly Engineering Associates, which represents Toudis LLC, the developer of the plaza. Toudis has been approved to take out a large retaining wall that was part of its first approval from the commission. The removal of the wall, which Thibeault said in June was estimated to cost $200,000, was made possible because Jimmie Moutoudis, owner of Toudis LLC, purchased an adjacent property and can now grade the slope. In August Toudis also asked for a change to the look of the building. Now, instead of one building which would house a Dunkin’ Donuts and other businesses, the Dunkin’ Donuts will stand alone with a 15-foot patio between it and the rest of the building. Thibeault said the overall footprint of the building remains the same. Moutoudis said he plans to use a new store design by Dunkin’ Donuts that would make the location one of only a handful in the country with that new look. “This will be a special place,” Toudis said. “There won’t be another Dunkin’ Donuts like it anywhere around here.” Moutoudis has indicated he wants to break ground as soon as possible. Syl Pauley, engineer for the Northeast Connecticut Council of Governments and the town engineer for Brooklyn, said the removal of the retaining wall and the new plan for grading the property meets all the necessary codes and standards. Community Development Director Jana Butts Roberson said the new landscape slope will be much more visually appealing than the retaining wall would have been. The slope will be landscaped with a small shrub native to the area. Roberson and Commission Vice Chairman Michelle Sigfridson had hoped to persuade Toudis to remove five parking spots meant for employees from its site plan. “I don’t think they are necessary,” Roberson said. “I think it will be more attractive without them.”Other commission members, however, felt that as long as the parking was within regulations they should not force Toudis to reduce parking spaces. “I think the employee parking spaces are a matter of personal preference to the extent it complies with our regulations and it’s reasonable, I have a hard time telling them not to put in the parking spaces,” commission member Jeryl Mohn said. AccuWeather.com Quick Look Change your current location » View Full Weather Report Search Search Search NJ.com Account Sign In Close Sign in to NJ.com You are signed in as Edit Public Profile Sign Out Subscribe Email newsletters The Star-Ledger The Times of Trenton The Jersey Journal South Jersey Times Hunterdon County Democrat Star Gazette comments Details emerge in shooting by police at Kearny Walmart wallmart.jpg The Walmart Supercenter in Kearny at 150 Harrison Ave. (File photo) Print Email Michaelangelo Conte | The Jersey Journal By Michaelangelo Conte | The Jersey Journal The Jersey Journal Follow on Twitter on September 16, 2016 at 5:50 PM, updated September 16, 2016 at 7:47 PM comments A man suspected of shoplifting at the Walmart in Kearny today was shot by a police officer when he drove his vehicle at the officer while trying to flee, the town's mayor said this afternoon. The accused shoplifter, Ramon Martinez, 43, of Newark, and a second man, Diego C. Dosreis, age 28, also of Newark, have been charged, Hudson County Prosecutor Esther Suarez said. Martinez is charged with eluding, receiving stolen property and shoplifting. Dosreis has been charged with receiving stolen property, Prosecutor's Office spokesman Ray Worrall said. The Kearny police officer who shot Martinez was not injured, but he was evaluated at a local hospital, which is standard procedure when an officer fires his weapon, Kearny Mayor Al Santos said. The officer, who was not identified, is a veteran of the force, the mayor said. Martinez was struck in "an extremity," the Prosecutor's Office said, and he is in stable condition at a local hospital. Santos said the shooting appeared to be justified. "The suspect is believed to have been a fleeing shoplifter and he threatened the officer with his vehicle," Santos said. "The officer had to respond. He shot at the suspect because he was threatened by the suspect's vehicle as he tried to get away from the police officer trying to apprehend him." Santos said the officer fired multiple shots and at least one struck Martinez in the parking lot of the store on Harrison Avenue.  The incident is being reviewed, as is customary, by the Hudson County Prosecutor's Office, which did not provide any further details on the incident. "When faced with an oncoming car, it seems to me it was an appropriate response," Santos said. "The incident is under review and if there are any questions, we will be looking at them." Santos credited his detectives for tracking down the shoplifter and his alleged accomplice. "The detective who were able to apprehend the suspect, their police work was outstanding," Santos said. "The suspect had fled after the shooting in the parking lot and the Kearny Detective Squad, based on information they collected at scene, were able to apprehend him later in Newark. "It's important that the suspect was arrested ... (as) it is also a deterrent because you know there is an effective response and police officers will be on the scene promptly and an arrest will be made." Subscribe   Login Login Signup View Newsletters Customer Care Subscribe NEWS Local News Obituaries Police & Courts Business Region & State Counties SPORTS Latest Sports Schools Scores Stats Pick 'em VIEWS Latest Views Blogs Columns Editorials Letters to the Editor Polls Everyday Heroes EXPLORE Projects Photos Photo Galleries Videos Reader Photos Elections Hurricanes FEATURES Latest Features Celebrations Education Entertainment Faith Food Health Home & Garden Magazines CLASSIFIEDS Classifieds Cars Homes Jobs Garage Sales Place an ad Marketplace 68° NEWS SPORTS OBITUARIES CLASSIFIEDS 68° STAY CONNECTED   Events Calendar SHARE THIS PAGE Share Tweet +1 It Pin It Reblog   Email   Print FOLLOW US ON   FACEBOOK   TWITTER PINTEREST INSTAGRAM Tumblr Advertise with us Victoria volunteers help flood victims in Louisiana Sept. 16, 2016 at midnight A multi-church team of volunteers from the Crossroads area assembled to help the flood victims of Baton Rouge. The group of 45 volunteers, ranging in age from 14 to 71, from area churches - Faith Family, Parkway Baptist, Northside Baptist, First English Lutheran, Emmanuel Lutheran in Inez and First Baptist of Lolita - gave up their Labor Day weekend to serve others devastated by the recent floods in Baton Rouge. This team personally saw to it that more than 8,000 square feet of buildings and homes were gutted and cleaned up to air out so that rebuilding can take place. Read more To read more about the trip see Barbara Breazeale's blog at victoriaadvocate.com/blogs/reader/entries/2016/sep/07/victoria-angels-work-flood-victims-september-6-2016/ To help If you want to help, please send a check or Wal-Mart gift cards to Bethany Church at 13855 Plank Road, Baker, LA 70714. You can contact Cameron Wiggins at 225-773-7581. Let them know how you want it used. Call or send to Faith Family Church, 2002 Mockingbird Lane, Victoria, TX 77903, 361-573-2484 and they will direct you. Talk to Outreach Pastor Mark Longoria. Scott Bauer, volunteer missions coordinator for Faith Family Church, helped organize a trip from Victoria to Louisiana to help flood victims. It became a multi-church effort with 45 volunteers ranging in age from 14 to 71 from Faith Family, Parkway, Northside Baptist and First English Lutheran churches making the Labor Day weekend trip. Victoria businessman Steve Seawalt donated two camper trailers to be used for flood victims to live in and four vehicles for single mothers. Below is a condensed blog post by Barbara Breazeale about the trip. Scott Bauer, a parishioner of Faith Family Church, had a great idea. He wanted to bring a crew from Victoria to Baker, La., and clean up flood debris. My husband, Bill Pozzi, told me about it this way, "Guess what? You and I are going to Louisiana." The people of Faith Family Church responded in volume, and 45 people left for long Labor Day weekend. Our destination was Bethany Church. When we arrived, we were greeted by unbelievable devastation at Bethany Church. The downstairs of this huge church and school had 3.5 to 4 feet of water inside it, and according to bystanders, "looked like huge indoor pool." All of the walls up to 4 plus feet were knocked out down to the studs. Carpet and flooring was ripped up and furniture had been ditched onto the front area. We were able to stay for free in their upstairs rooms, men in one wing and women in the other. They provided blow up mattresses and had trucks with showers in them for all the other volunteers who had come to help. More than 140 volunteers were in the building that weekend, some from Oklahoma, some from Tennessee. Bethany was sending out gut and clean teams. When you gut a home, they want all the wet drywall down to the studs removed, all furniture, all carpet, cabinets, all contents, so that the next team of "spray for mold" can come in. That is looked upon as homeowner or business' job, not insurance company. What was so amazing were the stories. I spoke to Betty Ann Thomas, who is on the Pastoral Support Team at Bethany. Their staff had been working 18 days with no break when we arrived, and their church is open 24 hours a day. Thomas said their church's first thought was to help widows, elderly and single moms. They put out an application for people to sign up for help, and they were inundated. This help was offered to everyone, not just people who went to Bethany Church. Thousands of homes were destroyed and people needed help. Most of the homes were not in a floodplain, and the residents had never experienced water of any kind. Ninety percent, including Bethany Church, did not have flood insurance. Thomas said her home was on very high ground so many people parked their vehicles at her house. She was on the front porch having coffee when it began to rain so hard that you could not see. The area received more than 33 inches of rain in less than 24 hours. When the rain slowed a bit, she saw a wall of water coming toward their house. All of the cars they were saving were destroyed and her house took on 6 feet of water. Luckily, she has flood insurance, but even that does not begin to cover all of it. Thomas has an amazing attitude about all of it. She says she gets teary-eyed when she thinks of the lost photos and sentimental items. She found her deceased father's picture in the water, shook it off and it had faded, but she was happy about that. I gave her gift card donated by an angel in Victoria and she cried. She sang to me her song, "Lord, I look to You" to describe her feelings. The first day, they asked me to help with phones as they were processing hundreds of people. I called for more than five hours, and the stories and tears were flowing. The rest of the crew went to a local church and gutted it. That story was amazing as well. The church has a small congregation and 4,000 square feet of building. They had prayer warriors praying to get help as their group tried to do as much as they could. The problem was, so many of their own were gutting their own houses. When the Faith Family "machine" arrived the congregation was in tears and felt their prayers had been answered. The machine gutted the entire place in half a day and took out all the contents to the street. I walked neighborhoods handing out gift cards donated by angels in Victoria Jerry Beezet is retired and in his 70s. He had lived in his neighborhood for more than 35 years, which never flooded. He broke down crying when I handed him a gift card. Beezet has no insurance and lost everything. One home, which took on water over the roof line, was just a stick house inside when I arrived. The residents said they had five crosses in their house. When they opened the door, chairs were slammed against windows and everything moved about the house, but the five crosses never moved. She smiled and said she knew God was with her. One of my favorite stories was Lucille Cooper, a lovely white-haired lady. For 40 years, she has lived in her home with her horses and six dogs. On the day when it rained and rained, she got her horses and dogs out and came back to secure some items. The back window blew out with huge wall of water and she ran to get into the attic. She looked out and the water was a foot from the bottom of the attic floor. She used her cellphone to call for help, and the first responder arrived on a Jet Ski. They cut a hole in her roof and she rode out on the Jet Ski. Her home is a total loss, and she is living in trailer until she decides what to do. She and I prayed together as well. I felt like crying, but she was smiling and OK. Everyone who made this trip will never be the same again. If you came with troubles and problems, you soon realized that yours were easy compared to what we saw. It restored your faith in God and humanity. Best Of The Beach Movies Calendar Contests More Entertainment Comics Puzzles & Games Horoscopes Celebrities Music TV Surge Legals Cars Jobs Moonlighting Homes Rentals Classifieds Classified Ads Local Deals About Us Community September 16, 2016 3:45 PM Myrtle Beach-area organizations need your help Saturday Wish List i LinkedIn Google+ Pinterest Reddit Print Order Reprint of this Story Donations/volunteers: Coastal Animal Rescue is in need of donations of cash, sheets, blankets, towels and volunteers. Golfers are needed for sixth annual golf tournament on Oct. 3, at Wachesaw Plantation. http://coastalanimalrescue.org/golf_home.html Volunteers: Phoenix Renaissance, Inc. is in need of a bookkeeper or accountant. Once known as the Racepath Community Association, in 1994 Phoenix Renaissance was incorporated as a 501 (c) 3 non-profit organization and expanded its outreach beyond the Racepath Community to all low-income families throughout Horry County. 843-283-3864 Volunteers: Neighbor to Neighbor is seeking volunteer office assistants to work at least one day a week from 10 a.m.-2 p.m. Monday – Friday. Duties vary but will require basic computer skills to learn the software used to match drivers with Neighbor’s needs. Located at 921 Kings Highway, Myrtle Beach. 843-353-0214 www.gracefullyaging.org Donations: Georgetown County Parks and Recreation is seeking donations for “Fund Your Park” program that runs through Sept. 23. The community’s help is needed to make enhancements to an upcoming project that will create lighted multipurpose fields and a six-lane athletic track on the grounds of Beck Recreation Center next year. To make a donation, www.gtcounty.org or go directly to http://fundyourpark.org/campaign/detail/4719 . Donations: AARP-South Carolina and the community are sponsoring a Veteran’s Stand Down, Sept. 23, in Myrtle Beach. Items needed are used eyeglasses, low denomination gift cards to fast food chains, Wal-Mart, etc. For pickup call 803- 873-2266 or dgleason@aarp.org Donations: Life Ministries and Walk Into Your Inheritance Outreach Ministries is accepting gently used clothes, coats and toys. Free clothing giveaway will be held 10 a.m. Sept. 24 at House Hold of Faith, 1290 Dennison Ave., Myrtle Beach. Donations can be dropped off at 507 N. Oak St., Myrtle Beach or 1757 Stanley Road, Supply N.C. 321-961-9913 or 910-294-0656 Volunteers: SC CARES needs two volunteer face painters, a cornhole board and bowling set (both sized for children) for their 10th “Animalversary” celebration to be held from 11 a.m.-4 p.m. Oct, 1, Pet Galley, 4484 U.S.17 Business, Murrells Inlet. Event includes, food, crafts, games, music, holiday gifts, jewelry, books and table top trees. 843-506-2688 or www.SC-CARES.org. Call for pick-up. Volunteers: SCORE provides free business mentoring services to help new and existing entrepreneurs grow their businesses. Would you like to be a SCORE volunteer? We have members who volunteer their time mentoring new and existing businesses, as well as teaching workshops/presentations, fundraising, and more. Previous business management, skills, or ownership experience is preferred. Apply at www.score.org/volunteer. Volunteers: Meals on Wheels of Horry County is in need of drivers to deliver meals to those in need in the Little River, Conway, and Myrtle Beach areas. If you have an hour and a half one day per week to help, 843-340-5982 or visit www.mowhc.org. Donations: Tara Hall Home for Boys is in need of cash donations to maintain our program of care, discipline, education and family for the boys in our care. Gift cards are a big help. Donations can be mailed to P.O. Box 955, Georgetown, SC 29442. 843-546-3000 Donations: The South Carolina Youth Advocate Program serves foster youth in the area. They are in need of school supplies, bunk beds, car seats, diapers, Wal-Mart or Target gift cards and monetary donations. Drop off donations or mail checks to 148 Elk Drive, Unit 4, Murrells Inlet, SC 29576. 843-238-9691 or lwatson@scyap.com Donations: Family Outreach is in need of baby formula, new or gently used infant, toddler, and children’s clothing newborn to size 5, infant and children’s socks, toddler and children’s underwear-new only, baby wash/lotion, baby bottles, diaper rash cream, baby nail clippers, nasal bulb, brushes/combs, copy paper, new book bags and school supplies. 843-234-2350 Donations: North Strand Housing Shelter is in need of paper towels, cleaning supplies, HE laundry detergent liquid or pods, heavy-duty, plastic forks, knives and spoons. Drop off donations at Mattress Direct, 587 U.S. 17, North Myrtle Beach or the shelter, 2335 S.C. 9 W., Longs. Also, in need of volunteers. 843-756-9488 or 843-421-4135. Donations: Friends of Surfside Library need paperback or hardback books, children’s books, puzzles, DVDs and CDs for monthly book sale. Leave at the circulation desk or 843-238-5869 or 843-238-5032 for pick up. No textbooks, magazines or encyclopedia. Donations: Humane Society of North Myrtle Beach is in need of paper towels, white and colored computer paper, kitten and puppy food, treats for dogs and cats, kitty litter, cat toys, pet beds, collars and leashes, bleach, dish and laundry soap. Donations can be dropped off at 409 Bay St. or 843-249-4948 or nmbhumanesociety@gmail.com Donations: The Salvation Army food pantry is in need of vegetables, soups, fruits, canned meats, cereals, pasta, rice, peanut butter, jelly, juice, and personal hygiene products. All nonperishable and hygiene items may be dropped off at any of the Horry County Family Store locations. Perishable items needed are hot dogs, ground beef and chicken; should only be dropped off at Food Pantry, 1415 Second Ave., Conway. 843-488-2769 or donation pickup 843-381-8080 Donations: All 4 Paws hears the voices of abandoned animals in our community. Clorox wipes, Dawn dishwashing detergent, HE laundry detergent, tall kitchen and 55-gallon garbage bags, Pine Sol, and paper towels. Items can be dropped off at: 708 Petigru Road, Pawleys Island. Visit All4PawsSC.org to volunteer, adopt or foster. Donations: Keep Our Pets Food Bank is in need of dry cat/dog food, wet cat/dog food, cat/dog treats, cat litter, beds - all sizes, toys and puppy pads. Call 843-651-0778 or keepourpetsfoodbank@yahoo.com. Items can be dropped off at 4764 U.S. 17 Bypass S., Murrells Inlet. Donations: The Friends of the North Myrtle Beach Library are accepting used books for its resale book racks. Please drop the books off at the library during regular library hours at 910 First Ave. S. The proceeds are used to purchase items for the library. 843-915-5281 Volunteers/donations: Sav-R-Cats is in need of volunteers to clean and maintain adoption center. Donations in need of HE laundry soap, window cleaner, paper towels, Purina Naturals cat food and monetary donations are always needed. 843-222-8057 Volunteers/donations: Bikini Beach Cat Rescue needs members of the community to become involved in the organization. Donations of money or time would be greatly appreciated. We help community residents with low-cost spay/neuters. If you have the time, please volunteer. We desperately need a grant writer, trappers, crates and people who can help with fundraisers and have ideas on ways to raise money. 843-655-7881 Volunteers/donations: Kind Keeper Animal Rescue is in need of volunteers for kennel clean up, office help, and event helpers. Donations needed are cleaning supplies, cat litter, canned dog and cat food, treats and more. View complete list on kindkeeper.org. 843-855-1398 or kindkeeper@yahoo.com. Volunteers/donations: Kare Team Sanctuary is in need of volunteers who are passionate about the rescue and rehabilitation of our canine friends. We need people who can commit to one or two afternoons per week for two to three hours. Foster homes are also needed. Donations of food, treats and/or toys, cleaning supplies and more are always needed. 843-399-9290 Volunteers/donations: Whiskers Animal Rescue and Sanctuary is looking for volunteers to help clean and maintain the cat sanctuary and kitten nursery, update social media sites, help with grant writing, foster and/or help with adoption events, craigslist sales of donated items, and fundraising. Donation needs are bleach, laundry detergent, wet and dry Friskies, Costco, Sam’s or Wal-Mart gift cards and used van. Kitty condos, scratching posts always welcome. We collect clean aluminum cans for recycling to raise funds to support the sanctuary. Located in the Loris area (just 4 miles from S.C. 22 and S.C. 905). 843-455-6199 or daren@warssc.org. Donations/volunteers: The Myrtle Beach Shore Birds, area representatives for the Quilt of Valor Foundation, are accepting monetary donations or patriotic fabric to make and award a comforting and healing quilt to give to service members and veterans. One quilt can cost up to $250 to complete. Your tax-deductible gifts buys fabric for quilt tops and backing, and pays for batting. We are looking for quilters to make tops and longarmers to quilt the tops. 843-902-7584 and jwobb@aol.com Information The Saturday Wish List is a place for nonprofit organizations or clubs to list their current needs. We will not publish anything regarding the exchange of labor for money or the exchange of items for money. The deadline is 5 p.m. Tuesdays. Submissions must be sent in on a weekly basis. Call the voicemail at 843-626-0282 or email features@thesunnews.com. Leave your name and contact information. Compiled by Lisa Urban. Are Banks Open on Black Friday 2016? Best Peer-to-Peer Lenders: Prosper, Lending Club and More Credit Cards Best Credit Card Rates How To Manage Credit Cards Credit Cards Tips 6 Pros and Cons of Store Credit Cards How Your Dallas Credit Card Benefits Can Save You Money Best Peer-to-Peer Lenders: Prosper, Lending Club and More follow us: About Us Contact Us Press Our Team Calculators Sitemap Privacy Policy Advertise Email Opt Out Careers GOBankingRates > Personal Finance > Holidays > Halloween > DIY Halloween Kids Costumes for Under $10 DIY Halloween Kids Costumes for Under $10 By Cameron Huddleston September 19, 2016 2 Comments ©Tomsickova Tatyana ©MimiCuteLips.com ©MomsandCrafters.com ©LynnaeMcCoy.com ©The Chic Site ©Erin Burt Monkey Business Images / Shutterstock.com ©Missiontosave.com ©Happydealhappyday.com ©Kleinworthco.com 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9 The spookiest time of year is back again — and it's out for your wallet. Between tricks, treats and costumes, Halloween spending was estimated to top $6.9 billion in 2015, with adults spending $74 each between costumes, candy and more, according to data from the National Retail Federation. But if you're hoping to celebrate Halloween on a budget, look no further. Here are nine low-cost Halloween costume ideas for your kids. 1. Owl Costume Mimi Green of MimiCutLips.com created an adorable owl costume for her daughter for less than $15. She used a hooded sweatshirt as the base and felt to create the feathers, which she sewed under each sleeve and on the front of a sweatshirt. You can use hot glue to attach the feathers, she said — just put cardboard inside the sweatshirt so the glue doesn’t soak through, and stick the sides together. She also used felt to create the owl face, which she stitched to the hood of the sweatshirt. To get this costume for under $10, pick up a used sweatshirt at a secondhand store, or use one you already own. Jo-Ann's frequently offers 40 to 60 percent off coupons for regular-priced items, too, and felt only costs $5.99 per yard, or $2.99 when on sale. 2. Carrot Costume The carrot costume Menucha Citron of MomsandCrafters.com made for her son didn’t require any sewing — just hot glue. She glued an orange piece of felt cut in the shape of a carrot to a shirt and paired it with orange pants. For the carrot top, she made a hat out of green burlap ribbon, using hot glue to hold it together. 3. Cow Costume Lynnae McCoy transformed her daughter into an adorable black-and-white cow on a budget using a long sleeve white shirt, black leggings and felt bought at Walmart. She used fabric glue to attach the black felt cut into spot shapes and pink felt for the udders. She found cow ears and a tail at Walmart to complete the look — but you can make one with felt to save on the cost. See: 10 Outrageously Expensive Halloween Costumes for Pets 4. Cactus Costume If you're trying to save this fall, look to this cactus costume from Rachel Hollis of The Chic Site. The blogger often relies on her DIY skills to make Halloween costumes for her boys. She once made cactus costumes for her and her son. All it took to make this clever costume: a green sweatshirt, sweatpants and pipe cleaners. Hollis cut the pipe cleaners into 2-inch pieces and glued them onto the sweats in groupings of one to four. 5. Jellyfish Costume If your kid wants to be a marine biologist when she grows up — as Erin Burt's daughter does — then a jellyfish is the perfect costume. And it certainly looks a lot cuter than the real thing. Burt glued pink material to an umbrella and then attached ribbon with hot glue to create tentacles. She dangled frilly white ribbon from the center of the umbrella to create the jellyfish's "oral arms," as Burt's daughter told her they are called. Then, her daughter held the umbrella over her head while trick-or-treating to give the illusion that she was a jellyfish. 6. Robot Costume What little boy wouldn’t love to be a robot for Halloween? Jamie Roubinek of Roubinek Reality was able to make her son look like one mainly with things she found around the house. She used two boxes covered in foil to create a robot body and head, then added an old CD, bottle caps, solo cups and printouts of gauges found online to accessorize. Dryer duct found at a home improvement store was used to cover her son’s arms and legs, and foil was wrapped around his shoes. 7. Cat in the Hat Costume Mary Hoover of MissiontoSave.com relied on Dr. Seuss for inspiration for costumes for her three sons. She turned her oldest into the Cat in the Hat using a black sweatshirt and sweatpants bought at a thrift store, white gloves, red felt for a bow, and a red and white hat that she bought but said could be made using felt if you sew. Read: 13 Children’s Books That Teach Money Lessons She dressed her younger sons as the Cat’s sidekicks — Thing 1 and Thing 2 — using red sweatsuits purchased at a thrift store, blue ski hats and blue yarn. She used white paint and a marker to create the Thing 1 and Thing 2 labels on their tops. Hoover said the yarn could be sewn or hot glued onto the caps to create hair. 8. Caterpillar Costume Maura White bought a monarch butterfly costume for her oldest daughter and wanted a costume for her toddler that would complement it. However, she couldn’t find a monarch caterpillar costume, so the frugal mom behind Happy Deal Happy Day opted to make one. She found a black and white romper on Amazon then used fabric markers to color every other stripe yellow. Then, White fashioned antennae out of black pipe cleaners attached to a black headband. 9. Day of the Dead Costume Here's an easy costume for under $10. Gina Kleinworth was inspired by sugar skulls used in the Mexican celebration of the Day of the Dead and decided to create a similar look on her daughter’s face for Halloween. This Day of the Dead costume only requires face paint — and a very steady hand. She added a large flower to her daughter’s hair to complete the look. You can find step-by-step instructions for creating a Day of the Dead face at her blog, Kleinworth Co. Up Next: 7 Things to Teach Your Kids About Credit and Money Next We Ranked the Winners of the 2016 Emmys by Their Net Worths View All Share This Article Throw a Killer Halloween Party for Under $50 15 Haunted Places You Can Visit for Under $50 Related Articles Crazy Things Your Kids Think About Money Spoiling Your Kids Is Costing You a Fortune How I Keep My Kids Entertained Without Spending a Fortune Best and Worst Things to Buy in September These responses are not provided or commissioned by the bank advertiser. Responses have not been reviewed, approved or otherwise endorsed by the bank advertiser. It is not the bank advertiser's responsibility to ensure all posts and/or questions are answered. We would love to hear your comments and feedback Mary I just love DIY Halloween costumes. They save money and make a memory. There are some really great ideas here. Thanks for sharing my Cat in the Hat, Thing 1 & Thing 2 post too. Mimi “MimiCuteLips” Green Thanks for the featuring my Owl Costume. DIY costumes can save you a lot of money but provide a lot of fun. Nothing sounds sweeter than “Mommy/Daddy made it for me.” Advertiser Disclosure * APY = Annual Percentage Yield Most Popular Personal Finance Articles ‘Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them’ Movie Cast Net Worth Post-Election: 1 in 3 Americans Are Not Confident in the Financial Future of the U.S. Economy 6 Car Repairs You Can (Really) Do Yourself 50 Stores With the Best and Worst Return Policies Most Viewed Personal Finance Video Fark Module Find Interest Rates Near Me Banking CD Rates Savings Account Checking Accounts Personal Loans Car Loans Mortgage Rates Credit Cards Go! Read today's eNewspaper News Maryland Harford County The Aegis Walmart expects to open expanded Abingdon store in 2019 Abingdon Walmart expansion MATT BUTTON | AEGIS STAFF / Baltimore Sun Expansion of the Walmart store in Abingdon is expected to begin in 2018 . The store would grow from 137,449 square feet to 187,627 square feet. The upgraded store is expected to open to the public in the spring of 2019. Expansion of the Walmart store in Abingdon is expected to begin in 2018 . The store would grow from 137,449 square feet to 187,627 square feet. The upgraded store is expected to open to the public in the spring of 2019. (MATT BUTTON | AEGIS STAFF / Baltimore Sun) Bryna ZumerContact ReporterThe Aegis Walmart's Abingdon store is expected to be bigger than Fallston's in 2019 Privacy Policy Walmart hopes to start construction on its Abingdon store expansion in 2018, with "minimal impact on store operations," the company said Wednesday. The Constant Friendship Boulevard retail store would grow from 137,449 square feet to 187,627 square feet, according to a site plan submitted earlier to the Harford County government. The expanded Abingdon store will be about 24,000 square feet larger than the Fallston Walmart that opened in 2011. The upgraded store is expected to open to the public in the spring of 2019, Erik Hingst, director of Walmart Public Affairs & Government Relations for Maryland, said via email. What's next for Bel Air South after Walmart pulled out? No big box stores, site's owner says BRYNA ZUMER A Walmart may no longer be looming for the Bel Air South area, but what's next for the empty plot of land at Route 924 and Plumtree Road? The site, surrounded by a wave of projects including the newly-completed MedStar Health and the soon-to-be-completed Avanti Luxury Apartments off of Route 24,... A Walmart may no longer be looming for the Bel Air South area, but what's next for the empty plot of land at Route 924 and Plumtree Road? The site, surrounded by a wave of projects including the newly-completed MedStar Health and the soon-to-be-completed Avanti Luxury Apartments off of Route 24,... (BRYNA ZUMER) "While this store has seen some interior and exterior improvements since it was opened in 1993, our plans for the expansion reflect our customer demand for a full complement of groceries, fresh fruits, vegetables, bakery goods and deli selections," Hingst said, noting "the planned expansion represents our commitment to those customers, our associates and the community." "Our goal is to continue to work with the elected officials, staff and the community in the open, transparent and professional manner they have established," Hingst said. Walmart held a community input meeting on the expansion in July. The company is expected to submit a plan for the Development Advisory Committee in the near future but has not done so yet, county government spokesperson Cindy Mumby said Thursday. After retreat from Bel Air South site, Walmart plans to expand Abingdon store BRYNA ZUMER Seven months after it called retreat from a contentious plan to build a new store in the Bel Air South area, Walmart has signaled it will expand its existing store in Abingdon's Constant Friendship business community, something company representatives had previously claimed couldn't be done. The... Seven months after it called retreat from a contentious plan to build a new store in the Bel Air South area, Walmart has signaled it will expand its existing store in Abingdon's Constant Friendship business community, something company representatives had previously claimed couldn't be done. The... (BRYNA ZUMER) The project marks a change of course for the company, which had previously tried to build a new store at Route 924 and Plumtree Road. A wave of community opposition ended with Walmart pulling out of the project last November. Company leaders had also claimed during the height of the controversy that expanding the existing Abingdon store was not feasible. Mike Pompeo for CIA director Channels Glenn Beck Dana Loesch Tomi Lahren Pat and Stu MyVoice Radio TV Login Join 0 www.theblaze.com Disabled Elderly Man Beaten in Wal-Mart Parking Lot — Then Disabled Veteran Shows Up Jon Street September 16, 2016 12:59 pm 0 123 Follow Share Tweet Police say a disabled elderly man in California was beaten in a Wal-Mart parking lot Tuesday by an unidentified man — and it all started over a parking spot. According to KTXL-TV, the unnamed victim approached the male suspect, whose girlfriend was driving the vehicle the couple was in, and accused the woman of parking illegally. That’s when things got heated. An unnamed suspect who police believe beat a disabled elderly man is seen in a Wal-Mart parking lot in Fairfield, California. (Image source: KTXL-TV) “All of a sudden, the guy just attacked him — older gentleman,” Chris Benett, who witnessed the incident with his girlfriend Suzie Fowler, said. “Opened up his door, grabbed him around his neck, punched him a couple of times.” Fowler added, “We have parents, too. It’s hard to imagine something like that happening to them. You don’t really think about your safety in that type of circumstance.” Benett, who is a disabled veteran, came to the rescue of the elderly man. Meanwhile, Fowler started to record the incident. The suspect and his girlfriend, realizing that they had met their match, took off in separate vehicles just moments later. But before they left, the suspect reportedly shouted at Fowler to stop recording. Fowler refused, and threatened to release her pitbull that was still in the car if he tried to touch her. Fairfield police are now looking for the suspect. Benett, for his part, is warning whoever the suspect is to turn himself in because “next time [he] might not be so lucky.” — Follow the author of this story on Twitter and Facebook: Follow @jonstreet Share Tweet Rate this story Recommended from the Web 123 Comments Show Comments Get TheBlaze Newsletters Sign Up Refer Friends, Earn Rewards! Skip the checkout and buy your groceries online Pat Ferrier , patferrier@coloradoan.com 8:22 p.m. MDT September 16, 2016 Skip Ad Ad Loading... x Embed x Share The New York Times looked into the probability that the check out lane at the grocery store would be the fastest. Patrick Jones (@Patrick_E_Jones) explains. Buzz60 Buy Photo Lori Arnold and Peta St. Aoro load groceries into a vehicle at the North College King Soopers Wednesday in Fort Collins. King Soopers has started offering online grocery ordering that can be picked up curbside. (Photo: Valerie Mosley/The Coloradoan)Buy Photo 77 CONNECTTWEETLINKEDIN 1 COMMENTEMAILMORE Dani Ullmann pulled up to the prescribed parking spot at North College Marketplace early Thursday. Within five minutes, she was headed home with a car full of groceries. Ullmann's pickup is part of King Soopers' new ClickList program that allows shoppers to order groceries online and pick them up curbside at its North Fort Collins store. King Soopers is the latest grocer to expand shoppers' options — from offering curbside pickup to home delivery — to cater to a customer base that often has more money than time. The service lets shoppers avoid checkout lines. For parents, it means no longer having to haul the kids out of the car and saying "no" to requests for candy bars and cookies. "It was awesome," said Ullmann, of Fort Collins. "It makes it easier to stick to a list and easier to stick to a budget. I got exactly what I wanted and was not in the store buying whatever." Typically, her weekly grocery bill is about $120. This day, it was $60. SHOPPING:  Sales slump at Loveland outlet mall Ullmann is among a growing consumer base redefining what it means "to go" to the store. Mary Blake and Abbey Irvine may also be converts. "Having just given birth to our second child, it is very convenient," Blake wrote in reply to a Coloradoan Facebook post. "Not only do I not need to bring the newborn out ... my husband can also swing by and pick (the groceries) up after work." Irving said grocery shopping with her two kids is no fun for anyone. Instead, she goes to her computer to virtually cruise store aisles. "I've shopped online at Walmart and love the convenience," Irvine said. Now she can add King Soopers to her list. "This is about meeting customers where they are,"  said Kelli McGannon, spokeswoman for King Soopers Colorado. "Some people will need home delivery. Some will like ordering online and picking groceries up on their way home from work. Some people just like to go to the grocery store." Whichever option works best for each consumer is where King Soopers wants to be. NEWS:  How sales taxes change your grocery bill Buy Photo King Soopers on North College Avenue in Fort Collins has started offering online grocery ordering that can be picked up curbside.  (Photo: Valerie Mosley/The Coloradoan) King Soopers offers ClickList in Greeley and will launch it at its 1275 Eagle Drive store in Loveland on Nov. 29. Walmart has a similar curbside program available at its Loveland store. Neither Albertsons nor Safeway has a similar program in Fort Collins, but the corporation that runs both chains recently launched home delivery in the Denver market. Customers were the driving force behind Albertsons' new service, said Kris Staaf, director of public affairs for Safeway and Albertsons in Colorado. Staaf said the company had more requests for home delivery in the Denver market than any other market in the country. For what may be the last marketplace to go digital, online ordering is the fastest-growing segment for the $675 billion U.S. grocery market. Grocers are setting the stage for what could be the next big opportunity for eCommerce, according to Morgan Stanley Research. More than a third of online shoppers expected to buy their groceries online this year, the company reported. Blurring the lines  According to Nielsen, a global company that studies consumer habits, grocery stores are blurring the lines between the physical and digital worlds. It's no surprise that a 2015 analysis of the future of grocery stores found 30 percent of millennials, ages 21-34, said they order groceries online for home delivery compared to 22 percent of Generation X (ages 35-49) and 17 percent of baby boomers. "Millennials are at the beginning of their careers and are starting to form households," said Nielsen's Patrick Dodd in the report. The generation "will shape our economy for decades to come, therefore it is critical that retailers understand how these consumers are using technology and include digital touch points along the entire path to purchase." Neither McGannon nor Staaf would quantify the success of their new programs for competitive reasons, but each said the programs have been well received. Peta St. Aoro at King Soopers said ClickList has served about 10 customers daily in its first week. BUSINESS NEWS:  Noosa Yoghurt sues competitor over similar packaging "People want options," Staaf said. "They want to be able to shop when they want, how they want.  We see people using the (delivery) service who are time-starved, living in urban areas. We're also seeing some people with limited mobility" who may need grocery delivery for a short time. McGannon said King Soopers has hired between seven and 10 additional staff at each store that offers curbside pickup. The service's cost, $4.95 per trip after the first three visits, is well worth it for people who value time more than money, although like Ullmann, McGannon says she saves money, too, because she avoids buying anything that's not on her shopping list. Ullmann's teenage daughter, Maria, likes curbside pickup because it saves time. "She takes so long in the store," she said about her mother. "She has a list but then goes through the aisles and says things like, 'I need this, I need this." Her mom is also a label reader, which means she makes healthier purchases, but takes much more time to find them. Buy Photo Lori Arnold loads groceries into a vehicle at the North College King Soopers Wednesday in Fort Collins. King Soopers has started offering online grocery ordering that can be picked up curbside.  (Photo: Valerie Mosley/The Coloradoan) How it works Ordering online is easy, especially for people who already shop the North College King Soopers. Log on to KingSoopers.com/ClickList, create an account, punch in your Soopers' card number and a slew of products will pop up on your screen. The items should look familiar; they're a sample of items you've recently purchased. Don't see what you need? Browse by department or type in the item and several choices will come up by size and brand. For those who like their bananas a little on the green side, or avocados that are ready to eat today, there's a spot to write notes to the employee who will fulfill your order. The order is stored in refrigerators and freezers until delivery time. When you arrive at the ClickList parking spots, call the store and they'll send your order out. FORT COLLINS:  Food Co-Op rooted in community It took less than two minutes for clerks to arrive with Ullmann's order, she said. It took another five minutes to load and pay. If she hadn't stopped to talk to a reporter she would have been headed home within 10 minutes of arriving. When your order is complete, you can pay with a credit card online or check when you arrive to pick up your order at a prescribed time between 7 a.m. and 8 p.m., McGannon said. "Our goal is to stay focused on the customer and the customer is changing," she said. Who offers online options? King Soopers: Curbside pickup at North College Marketplace, 1842 N. College Ave. Home delivery is also available throughout Fort Collins.  Kingsoopers.com/ClickList. Orders must be placed 24 hours in advance. Cost: $4.95 per order, although the first three orders are free.   Safeway/Albertsons: Home delivery available in Denver metro area. The corporation is exploring expansion into other markets. Cost is based on delivery time, between $6.95 and $9.95.  Walmart: Curbside pickup available at Loveland store, 1325 Denver Ave. $30 minimum order. Pickup hours between 8 a.m. and 8 p.m. Service is free. 77 CONNECTTWEETLINKEDIN 1 COMMENTEMAILMORE Read or Share this story: http://noconow.co/2cswQEV TOP VIDEOS Which stores are opening, closing Thanksgiving Day 0:34 Why it's time to change your holiday shopping plans 0:35 Cuban coffee available in U.S. for first time in over 50 years 0:40 Girl Scout cookie cereal is a real thing and happening soon 1:10 Pennies worth $1k hidden across U.S. 0:39 What college students really buy with student loans 0:36 Major retailers buck trend of starting Black Friday on Thanksgiving 1:09 Toyota recalls Prius cars over faulty brakes 0:30 America's biggest mall makes bold Thanksgiving move 0:23 Elizabeth Warren rips into Wells Fargo CEO 0:52
Two cited in clown incident outside Thomson Walmart - WFXG FOX 54 Augusta - Your News One Hour Earlier Member Center: Create Account| Log In Manage Account| Log Out SITE SEARCHWEB SEARCH BY HOME News & Weather Apps NEWS Local News Georgia News South Carolina News National News Crime News Education News Military News Health News Tech Elections WEATHER Hurricane season 2016 Weather and disaster coverage Interactive Radar Weather Alerts Georgia River Levels from NWS Pollen Count SPORTS 2016 Paralympic Games SEC Coverage ACC Digital Network ACC Video Vault Entertainment CSRA Entertainment Entertainment News Video Right This Minute Video Most Popular Videos TV WFXG TV Listings FOX On Demand TMZ Children's Television Programming Reports Community For Our Children High 5 4 Kids 2 Strong 4 Bullies Community Calendar Angel Tree Contests Hardee's Tailgate Takeout Southern Siding Home Makeover Watch, Text, and Win with Family Feud ABOUT US Contact Us WFXG-TV transmitter upgrade News Team Meet Our Staff Closed Captioning Concerns EEO Public File FCC Public Inspection Files Digital Sales Jobs at WFXG Advertise With Us Two cited in clown incident outside Thomson Walmart 2016-09-16T14:45:21Z2016-09-16T14:58:25Z By Michelle Jackson Email Connect mjackson@wfxg.com Photo of a clown (Karen Ellot / Flickr) Two teenagers have been cited in one of the incidents involving clown masks at the Thomson Walmart. The McDuffie County Sheriff’s Office says 18-year-old Christopher Hayes and 18-year-old Joshua Hadden are both charged with disorderly conduct. According to an incident report from Thursday evening, the teens admitted to trying to scare people. Just before 10:30 p.m., one teen was wearing the clown mask as he drove through the parking lot. Witnesses were able to give a license plate number to investigators. That’s what led deputies to question the teens. The mask was found in the Walmart parking lot. Investigators say there is no evidence tying these two suspects to the incident at the bus stop in the Davis Circle area. That incident is still under investigation. Hayes and Hadden are scheduled to appear in McDuffie County Magistrate Court on October 20, 2016 at 3 p.m. The McDuffie County Sheriff’s Office is thanking the public for the help in solving this case. Home Best of Benzinga Careers About Contact Us Partners Benzinga Fintech Awards News Earnings Guidance Dividends M&A Buybacks Legal Interviews Management Retail Sales Offerings IPOs Insider Trades Biotech/FDA Markets Pre-Market After Hours Movers Forex Commodities Options Binary Options Bonds Futures Global Economics Previews Reviews Small-Cap Ratings Analyst Color Downgrades Upgrades Initiations Price Target Ideas Long Ideas Short Ideas Technicals From The Press Jim Cramer Rumors ETFs Tech Start-Ups Fintech Personal Finance Premium Products My Watchlist Market Overview Tickers Articles Keywords Search by keyword...googlecse Wal-Mart Isn't Exciting 'But Better Than Many Staples Retail Alternatives' Monica Gerson , Benzinga Staff Writer   {{following ? "Following" : "Follow"}} September 16, 2016 8:57am   Comments Share: Related WMT Mid-Afternoon Market Update: Children's Place Rises On Strong Q3 Results; DryShips Shares Tumble 20 Biggest Mid-Day Losers For Thursday Wall Street Breakfast: Major Overhaul At Volkswagen (Seeking Alpha) Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (NYSE: WMT) witnessed a return of traffic growth against a deteriorating environment. Although there’s nothing very exciting, the company is “better than many staples retail alternatives,” Credit Suisse’s Edward J. Kelly said in a report. He assigned an Outperform rating and $80 price target on Wal-Mart, versus the previous Neutral rating and $62 price target. Wal-Mart witnessed traffic growth due to its in-store investments and improvement in low-end consumer. While stating that this progress was “encouraging,” given the worsening staples retail landscape, “there is more work to do,” Kelly commented. As management makes further investments, Wal-Mart’s top-line momentum would likely continue. Related Link: Wal-Mart Investments In Low-Pricing Put Pressure On Everyone From Grocers To Dollar Stores Structural Headwinds “E-commerce, accelerating brick-and-mortar competition, an over-reliance on "Big Food" to drive traffic, a general lack of differentiation in its stores outside of price, and ongoing deflation represent meaningful headwinds for WMT,” Kelly wrote. He added that management was investing heavily to address the issue and strengthen Wal-Mart’s competitive position in the US. Key Driver Of Stock Performance U.S. comp growth has been the key driver of Wal-Mart’s stock performance and should continue. Although comp growth of 1.0-1.5 percent “isn't overly impressive,” several peers have witnessed declines, Kelly noted. He added, “Further investments should drive continued top-line gains, although the ultimate return is still uncertain.” Do you have ideas for articles/interviews you'd like to see more of on Benzinga? Please email feedback@benzinga.com with your best article ideas.
