Back Area Police Beat Eriangel Diaz, 21, who was already incarcerated at the Citrus County Detention Facility (arrested Aug. 31) on similar charges, was arrested on additional charges of various thefts from the Inverness Walmart. Sept. 1: one count of grand retail theft, two counts of retail petit theft (value more than $100, but less than $300), two counts of retail petit theft (value less than $100), four counts of trafficking or endeavoring to traffic in stolen property and grand theft of $300 or more, but less than $5,000. His total bond was set at $24,000. He's accused of taking 3 items from the store to the service desk for a $99.08 gift card on Aug. 18; taking 6 items from the store to the service desk on Aug. 18 for a gift card of $242.82; taking 7 items from the pharmacy department on Aug. 26 and returning them to the service desk for a $125.51 gift card, then walking out of the store with a table valued at $26.48 without attempting to pay for it, then of returning 24 items for a gift card of $796.07; then on Aug. 27, taking 8 items with a value of $328.66 to the service desk, but being declined for a cash refund. The report stated that the transactions were captured on store surveillance.   Scott Matthew Walsh, 51, Hernando, was arrested by the Citrus County Sheriff's Office, Sept. 1, charged with aggravated battery using a deadly weapon (bond ($10,000).   Sara LaVone White, 32, 202 Edison St., Inverness, was arrested by the Citrus County Sheriff's Office, Sept. 1 on a Citrus County warrant for battery (bond $1,000).    Nicholas William Cooper, 26, 1394 W. Brandywine St., Lecanto, FL, was arrested by the Citrus County Sheriff's Office, Sept. 2, charged with criminal mischief of $1,000 or more. The arrest report stated, according to witnesses, Cooper arrived at the victim's workplace in Inverness, pounding on windows, trying to get inside, then began kicking and punching the victim's vehicle. The victim told deputies that Cooper was extremely intoxicated, according to the report. The report also stated that a side mirror of the vehicle was shattered and loose, a front tire was slashed, and there were multiple dents and footprints on the drivers door, the rear driver’s side door and the driver’s side window. Damages to the vehicle were estimated at $1,500.   Richard Clarence Miller, IV, 21, Panama City Beach, FL, was arrested by the Citrus County Sheriff's Office, Sept. 2, charged with possession of a controlled substance and driving while license suspended or revoked (knowingly, first offense). His total bond was set at $3,000. The arrest was the result of a traffic stop in Homosassa for a driver's license check, as the deputy recognized him and verified through the AEGIS system that he had no current valid license. After gassing up the vehicle, the other driver drove away, but deputies (and surveillance at the gas station) had already seen Miller driving earlier. He was also found to be in possession of methamphetamine.   Jason Michael Pounders, Sr., 3442 E. Deer Run Ln., Hernando, was arrested by the Citrus County Sheriff's Office, Sept. 2, on a Citrus County warrant for parent failing to require that a minor student attend school. His bond was set at $500.   Kyle William Allen, 30, Dunnellon, was arrested by the Williston Police Department, Sept. 3, during a traffic stop for erratic driving. The report stated that he was weaving between lanes, speeding occasionally at 10 mph above the posted speed, alternating with slowing the vehicle's speed. He was unsteady on his feet and had difficulty conversing with police as he couldn't remember the conversational thread, according to the report, which also stated that he refused to submit to breath alcohol testing. He was charged with driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs (surety/cash bond $5,000) and knowingly driving while license suspended or revoked (surety/cash bond $5,000).    Lisa Ann Clancy, 51, 6615 W. Pahalie Ct., Crystal River, was arrested by the Citrus County Sheriff's Office, Sept. 3, charged with operating a vehicle without a valid driver's license and driving under the influence with damage to property (total bond $1,500). Corbitt Ave. Clancy was the driver of a friend's vehicle. According to the arrest report, Clancy exhibited signs of intoxication and admitted to having consumed two wine coolers earlier. She agreed to roadside sobriety testing and performed poorly, the report stated.   Holly Eileen Marie Hockenberry, 39, 222 S. Monroe St., Beverly Hills, was arrested by the Citrus County Sheriff's Office, Sept. 3, on a Citrus County warrant for obtaining property by means of a worthless check; bond $2,000.00.   Mitchell James Kelley, 35, Homosassa, was arrested by the Citrus County Sheriff's Office, Sept. 4, charged with criminal mischief of $200 or less and aggravated assault with a deadly weapon without intent to kill (total bond $2,500). According to accounts of witnesses, the victim and Kelley, Kelley and the victim got into an argument due to a relative telling Kelley that she suspects the victim of an attempt to burglarize her property, several nights previously. The victim and a witness stated they thought, but did not see, Kelley breaking the window of a camper. Video surveillance showed the victim walking with a stick, then Kelley and another person walking onto the victim's property, the victim pushing Kelley, another person giving Kelley a walking stick, and Kelley and the victim swinging the sticks. The surveillance video did not show either of the two hitting the other. Due to the facts, circumstances and video, the report stated, Kelley was placed under arrest after he was examined at Seven Rivers Regional Medical Center in Crystal River due to several abrasions.   An 18 year-old Floral City youth was arrested on a felony charge, possession of a controlled substance, Sept. 5. Calais Ter., Homosassa, was arrested by the Citrus County Sheriff's Office, Sept. 6, on a Hernando County warrant for 21 counts of exploitation of an elderly or disabled person less than $10,000; 4 counts of fraud - illegal use of a credit card, and 1 count of grand theft of $300 or more, but less than $5,000. Gardenia Dr., Dunnellon, was arrested by the Citrus County Sheriff's Office, Sept. 6, charged with a misdemeanor, leaving the scene of a crash with property damage ($500 bond). The arrest report stated that  deputies met with the complainant at U.S. Hwy. 19 and McKinley St. where, she said, a black Cadillac struck the rear of her vehicle while she was stopped in the median break. She said the female driver smiled at her as she pulled away. A short time later, the driver and the black Cadillac were located in Homosassa at a S. Candy Lane Dr. residence. Ms. Natiello told deputies that her vehicle was smoking and she left the scene of the crash because she was afraid. She gave deputies details of the crash, plus there was sufficient evidence that Ms. Natiello's vehicle was the vehicle in question due to the damages, a lost Cadillac part at the crash site and red paint transfer on the right front fender.   Crystal Nadine Rollen, 26, 10770 N.Manhattan Pt., Dunnellon, was arrested by the Citrus County Sheriff's Office, Sept. 6, charged with burglary of an unoccupied residence (bond $10,000). Ms. Rollen is accused of taking items from a N. Dunedin Rd., Dunnellon, residence. The report stated that Rollen contacted the victim by phone, allegedly admitting that she'd stolen items from his residence and asking to meet with him at a Crystal River auto parts store so he could buy the items back from her. The victim agreed to meet her at the store, then contacted deputies about the proposed meeting details. Deputies went to the store and found Rollen sitting on a curb at the side of the building. She was in possession of a DVD player, three nail guns and a Volkswagon key - items reported as being taken in the burglary. Rollen professed her innocence and gave deputies the name of a man she said had committed the crime. However, the man denied involvement when deputies contacted him by phone. The report stated that deputies were called to U.S. Hwy. 19 and NW Snug Harbor Rd. due to a disturbance on a Greyhound Bus. As the call came in, the deputy happened to be driving by the bus, and the bus driver was flagging him down. The deputy stopped. The driver told the deputy that a passenger was lying on the floor, yelling and going crazy, the report stated, and he appeared to be under the influence of some type of narcotic. The deputy escorted Stevens off the bus, and had to catch Stevens to stop him from falling. The deputy patted Stevens down and found the items.   Thomas Declan Ebbert, 23, 2040 N. Twig Pt., Inverness, was arrested by the Citrus County Sheriff's Office, Sept. 7, charged with possession of a controlled substance (0.3 gm methamphetamine), driving while license suspended or revoked knowingly and possession of cannabis less than 20 grams (approximately 1 gm). His total bond was set at $3,500. The report stated that the vehicle Ebbert was driving stopped abruptly (at 2:19 am) at a closed business located at 2821 W. Dunnellon Rd., Dunnellon. The deputy learned that the tag on the vehicle was assigned to another vehicle, Ebbert's driver's license had been suspended for failure to pay traffic fines, and Ebbert had an arrest warrant for failure to appear. The vehicle was searched, due to Ebbert's arrest, and the drug was found.    Maleem Fleming, 27, U.S. Virgin Islands, was arrested by the Citrus County Sheriff's Office, Sept. 7, on a Broward County warrant for aggravated battery using a deadly weapon, His bond was set at none.   Heather LeAnn Gilmore, 34, 69 N. Sheltering Oaks Dr., Inverness, was arrested by the Citrus County Sheriff's Office, Sept. 7, charged with possession of a controlled substance (0.5 gm methamphetamine). Her bond was set at $2,000. The arrest came as the result of a traffic stop in Beverly Hills for not coming to a complete stop at a stop sign and also of driving erratically after the traffic infraction. She gave permission for her vehicle to be searched, and the drug was found during the search.   James Lewis Miller, 30, 6525 S. Bobwhite Dr., Homosassa, was arrested by the Citrus County Sheriff's Office, Sept. 7, charged with felony possession of a controlled substance (33.5 gms marijuana) and possession of drug paraphernalia (a digital scale and 3 plastic baggies). His bond was set at $3,000. The arrest was the result of a complaint of a suspicious person sitting in a Honda Civic in a vacant lot near a Homosassa residence. While driving in the area of the complaint, deputies saw the vehicle driving away, and the deputy followed it until the car turned into the Circle K gas station and parked. The deputy asked the occupants to roll down a window, and when it was rolled down, smoke billowed out, and the deputy smelled cannabis. The vehicle was searched, and the items were found. Miller was a rear seat passenger. Another passenger was issued a notice to appear citation for possession of cannabis (less than 20 gms) and released on his own recognizance.   Amanda Iris Moore, 26, of Homosassa, was arrested by the Citrus County Sheriff's Office, Sept. 7, on numerous charges related to three different cases. She was already an inmate at the Citrus County Detention Facility since Sept. 2, when she was arrested on a failure to appear warrant. In one case, she was charged with uttering a forged check in the amount of $486.79 from the Homosassa Riverside Resort and cashed at the Crystal River Publix on May 28, 2016 (bond $2,000). In a second case, she accused of uttering a forged check in the amount of $491.33 from the Homosassa Riverside Resort and cashing it at the Publix, located at 9525 S. Suncoast Blvd., Homosassa, on May 26, 2016 (bond $2,000). In a third case, Moore is accused of uttering a forged check in the amount of  $483.77 from the Homosassa Riverside Resort and cashing it at the Chevron Quik Stop, located at 118 NW U.S. Hwy. 19, Crystal River, on May 28, 2016 (bond $2,000).   Jacob Russell Perin, 24, Inverness, was arrested by the Citrus County Sheriff's Office, Sept. 7, charged with felony domestic battery by strangulation (no bond).   Bryan Clarence Reynolds, 39, 11130 W. Yemassee Ln., Homosassa, was arrested by the Citrus County Sheriff's Office, Sept. 7, charged with possession of a controlled substance (0.2 gm methamphetamine). His bond was set at $2,000. The arrest came as the result of a traffic stop in Old Homosassa, at 11:15 pm, for riding a bicycle with no front or rear lights. Reynolds was searched, and the drug was found in two small packets. During the stop, Reynolds discussed his use of methamphetamine for about two years and asked for some form of rehabilitation during his interview, the report stated.   Scott Anthony Gideon, 44, 8620 W. Mayo Dr. Apt. 44, Crystal River, was arrested by the Citrus County Sheriff's Office, Sept. 8, charged with a misdemeanor, disorderly intoxication (bond $500). The report stated that Gideon and his roommate were involved in an argument about a recent pawn of their television. The two were given a stern warning form the deputy in regard to their level of their intoxication and the number of calls related to disturbing the peace at the residence (four calls on Aug. 31, two calls on Sept. 2, two calls on Sept. 4 and one call on Sept. 5). About an hour later, the sheriff's office received a complaint from a neighbor, that Gideon was screaming and banging on the walls, asking his roommate to let him in. This time he was arrested.   Shanna Lee Holwager, 41, homeless in the area near the Homosassa Library in Homasassa, was arrested by the Citrus County Sheriff's Office, Sept. 8, charged with trespassing at the RaceTrac gas station. Her bond was set at $1,000. The manager complained that Holwager was getting into verbal arguments with customers. Deputies found her, lying on the ground, near the building, at the rear of the business. She had previously been trespassed from the business on Jan. 14, 2016, the report stated.   Jashon Mobley, 31, homeless in the Crystal River area, was arrested by the Citrus County Sheriff's Office, Sept. 8, charged with petit theft (value less that $100) and burglary of an unoccupied structure, with his total bond set at $5,250. The report stated that Mobley is accused of making forced entry into the General Store, located at 639 N. Citrus Ave., Crystal River, on Aug. 2. and taking $35 in cash from the cash register. Fingerprints were taken from the burglary scene, and the results came back on Sept. 7 as matching Mr. Mobley's fingerprints. Mr. Mobley was located at 855 NE 5th St., Crystal River and taken into custody. He denied involvement in the burglary.  
About Future Staff Contact Privacy Policy Search for: Select Press Releases Home / Press Releases / Mediaplanet and YMCA of the USA Team Up to Fight Hunger in America Mediaplanet and YMCA of the USA Team Up to Fight Hunger in America Posted on September 16, 2016 by Top News US Full Feed in Press Releases Conceptual image of a businessman holding big hammer September 16th, 2016— Mediaplanet today announces the newest edition of our “Feeding Our Nation” campaign. New York, NY (PRWEB) September 16, 2016 The annual campaign returns to shed light on the different ways we are helping end hunger in America. From exclusive interviews, resources and inspirational stories, “Feeding Our Nation” tackles the variety of problems that we are dealing with in our country regarding hunger, and ways that we can do individually to make it a thing of the past. It also provides insight to the developing trends and tech within the industry, from leading advocates and associations—namely YMCA of the USA. The aim of this campaign will be to raise awareness to our readers for Hunger in America, and inspire action ranging from making donations, volunteering, and supporting the organizations that have amazing hunger initiatives. From childhood to senior hunger, and everything in between, we have found amazing solutions to help make hunger a thing of the past. One company that is going above and beyond to help fight hunger in America is YMCA of the USA. To help kids stay healthy, succeed in school and reach their full potential, the Y feeds kids throughout the summer and afterschool, thanks to support from the Walmart Foundation. Combining educational and physical activity, the programs keep kids’ minds and bodies active, while also serving a healthy to kids who may otherwise be at risk of hunger when the school day ends. Last year, the Y served over 485,000 kids nearly 18 million meals and snacks nationwide. The print component of “Feeding Our Nation” is distributed within the weekend edition of USA Today in New York, Los Angeles, Washington D.C./Baltimore, and New Orleans markets with a circulation of approximately 250,000 copies and an estimated readership of 750,000 people. The digital component is distributed through a vast social media strategy, across a system of top news sites and partner outlets. About YMCA of the USA The Y is one of the nation’s leading nonprofits strengthening communities through youth development, healthy living and social responsibility. Across the U.S., 2,700 Ys engage 22 million men, women and children – regardless of age, income or background – to nurture the potential of children and teens, improve the nation’s health and well-being, and provide opportunities to give back and support neighbors. Anchored in more than 10,000 communities, the Y has the long-standing relationships and physical presence not just to promise, but to deliver, lasting personal and social change. About Mediaplanet Mediaplanet is the leading independent publisher of content-marketing campaigns covering a variety of topics and industries. We turn consumer interest into action by providing readers with motivational editorial, pairing it with relevant advertisers and distributing it within top newspapers and online platforms around the world. Reiterated Economy US Europe Asia Global Economic Calendar Economic Scorecard Fed Members Markets Morning Mkt Analysis US Commentary European Commentary Asian Commentary Canadian Commentary Indian Commentary Commodities Bonds Currencies Politics US World White House Elections Congress General News Forex FX Top Stories Currency Analysis Currency Alerts Economic Calendar Economic Scorecard Health Hot Topics Diet & Fitness Kids Health Men's Health Women's Health Cancer News Drug Development Mental Health Tech Hot Topics Gadgets & Games Mobile Green Tech Entertainment Top Stories TV News Movie News Slide Shows Game of Thrones Music news Pop Rock Classic Rock Rap/Hip-Hop Country Alternative Oldies All Genre Content Licensing Newswires & Feeds Content Syndication Digital Signage Services Radio News Services Premium Emerging Biostocks Under The Radar Short-Term Investor NewsStream Login More Free Content RSS Feeds Search Blog Political Science / Nature Fundamental Analysis Columns Science & Tech Arts & Leisure Politics & Policy Money   E-MAIL  SHARE FONT-SIZE    Tweet Share Inflation Data Renews And Aggravates Rate Hike Worries 9/16/2016 8:55 AM ET The major U.S. index futures are pointing to a lower opening on Friday after some fairly innocuous data in terms of their implications for Fed rates offered some solace yesterday. The recent trigger that has brought up rate hike worries all over again is the U.S. consumer price inflation report for August, which came in more than expected, signaling that there is some scope for upward maneuvering of rates. Commodities are all in the red, as the dollar is firming up. In the absence of any major catalysts, traders may prefer to be on the sidelines or lighten their holdings ahead of next week's two major central bank decisions. U.S. stocks advanced solidly on Thursday, with tempered rate hike fears serving as a spring board for the markets to rebound from recent weakness. The major averages opened higher, as traders digested a slew of soft domestic data, which allayed fears concerning a near-term interest rate hike. The averages rose steadily before ending notably higher. The Dow Industrials added 177.71 points or 0.99 percent before ending at 18,213, the S&P 500 Index closed 21.49 points or 1.01 percent higher at 2,147 and the Nasdaq Composite ended at 5,250, up 75.92 points or 1.47 percent. All thirty Dow components closed the session higher, with Apple (AAPL), Intel (INTC), Merck (MRK), Microsoft (MSFT), UnitedHealth (UNH), Caterpillar (CAT), Wal-Mart (WMT) and Procter & Gamble (PG) leading the gains. Among the sectors, semiconductor, computer hardware, brokerage, energy and biotechnology stocks showed notable moves to the upside. On the economic front, the Labor Department reported that jobless claims rose to 260,000 in the week ended September 10th from 259,000 in the previous week. The four-week average eased to 260,750 from 261,250. Continuing claims calculated with a week's lag were little changed at 2.143 million in the week ended September 3rd. The Commerce Department reported that retail sales slipped 0.3 percent month-over-month in August following a revised 0.1 percent gain in July. Excluding autos, retail sales declined a more modest 0.1 percent compared to the 0.4 percent decline in July. Auto sales fell 0.9 percent following July's 1.7 percent jump. The decline in building material and garden equipment store sales steepened to 1.4 percent from 0.7 percent. Miscellaneous store and non-store retail sales also saw notable decreases. However, the drop in furniture and home furnishing store sales slowed to 0.7 percent from 1.1 percent and electronic store sales rebounded by 0.1 percent. Food and beverage sales rebounded. Gasoline store sales fell at a slower pace of 0.8 percent. A separate Commerce Department report showed that business inventories remained virtually unchanged in July compared to the previous month. Annually, inventories climbed 0.5 percent. Business sales edged down 0.2 percent month-over-month and were 0.8 percent lower from last year. The business inventories/sales ratio rose to 1.39 in July from 1.37 in the year-ago period. The Labor Department report on producer prices showed tame inflationary pressure. The producer price index for final demand was unchanged in August compared to the previous month, while economists expected a 0.1 percent increase. The core producer price index for final demand rose at a faster 0.3 percent clip compared to a flat reading in June. The results of the Philadelphia Federal Reserve's business outlook survey showed that its diffusion index of business activity rose sharply to 12.8 in September from 2 in August. However, the inner details were mixed. The new orders index rose to 1.4 from -7.2, while the unfilled orders index was at an anemic -10.8. The shipments index and the employee index were also in negative territory. Meanwhile, the New York Federal Reserve's survey showed that manufacturing activity in the region continued to contract in September. The general business conditions index improved to -1.99 in September from -4.21 in August, while economists expected a reading of -1. The new orders and unfilled orders indexes were at -7.45 and -11.61, respectively. The employment index is deep in the red at -14.29. Industrial production fell 0.4 month-over-month in August, according to a report released by the Federal Reserve. Economists expect a 0.2 percent drop. Manufacturing output also declined 0.4 percent, reversing the 0.4 percent increase in July and steeper than the 0.3 percent drop expected by economists. Capacity utilization eased 0.4 percentage points to 75.5 percent. Currency, Commodity Markets Crude oil futures for October delivery are slipping $0.83 to $43.08 barrel after rising $0.33 to $43.91 a barrel on Thursday. Gold futures are currently trading at $1,312.80 an ounce, down $5 from the previous session's close of $1,318 an ounce, which represented a 2-week low. On Thursday, gold fell $8. 10. On the currency front, the U.S. dollar is trading at 102.01 yen compared to the 102.10 yen it fetched at the close of New York trading on Thursday. Against the euro, the dollar is valued at $1.1201 compared to yesterday's $1.1244. Asia Asian stocks rebounded from a six-week low, encouraged by Wall Street's rally overnight. The markets in China, Hong Kong, Malaysia, South Korea and Taiwan were closed for public holidays. The Japanese market rose as the yen remained subdued at the lower 102-levels. The Nikkei 225 Index opened higher and moved roughly sideways in a broad range in the morning before advancing in the afternoon. The index ended up 114.28 points or 0.70 percent at 16,519. The Australian market rose for a third straight day, as easing Fed rate hike worries helped lift stocks across the board. The All Ordinaries index closed up 59.60 points or 1.12 percent at 5,397. The market witnessed broad based strength, with utility, telecom, consumer discretionary and financial stocks making strong advances. Europe The European markets moved about in a lackluster manner in the morning after rebounding from a 5-session decline yesterday. The averages opened higher but saw a volatile bout in the morning. The averages are currently notably lower, as U.S. inflation data has served to intensify the weakness. In major corporate news, Deutsche Bank (DB) said it has no intent to pay the $14 billion sought by the U.S. Justice Department to settle potential civil claims anywhere near the number cited. U.S. Economic Reports Consumer prices in the U.S. increased by slightly more than expected in the month of August, according to a report released by the Labor Department. The Labor Department said its consumer price index rose by 0.2 percent in August after coming in unchanged in July. Economists had expected prices to inch up by 0.1 percent. Excluding food and energy prices, core consumer prices climbed by 0.3 percent in August after edging up by 0.1 percent in July. Core prices had been expected to rise by 0.2 percent. The University of Michigan is scheduled to release its preliminary U.S. consumer sentiment index for September at 10 am ET. The index is expected to increase to 90.8 from 89.8. Stocks in Focus Oracle (ORCL) reported below-consensus results for its first quarter and issued weak earnings forecast for the second quarter, as its traditional software business weakens. Authentic Brand Group (ABG), General Growth Properties (GGP) and Simon Property Group (SPG) finalized the acquisition of Aeropostale. Standard & Poor's announced that Avis Budget (CAR) will replace Questar (STR) in the S&P MidCap 400 Index after the close of trading on September 16th. This follows Questar being acquired by Dominion Resources (D). by RTT Staff Writer For comments and feedback: editorial@rttnews.com Top Ten Corporate Comeback Stories The Most Influential Books In Business Fed Chatterbox: Economic Preview Week of November 14 Please enable JavaScript to view the comments powered by Disqus. comments powered by Disqus Follow RTT Editor's Pick Most Read Most Emailed Volkswagen To Cut 23,000 Jobs In Germany Cyber Monday Sales Seen Soaring LinkedIn Is Now Blocked In Russia Facebook Stops WhatsApp Data Sharing Across Europe Over EU Criticism Wal-Mart Q3 Profit Declines, But Lifts FY17 Profit View; AccuWeather.com Quick Look Change your current location » View Full Weather Report Search Search Search AL.com Account Sign In Close Sign in to AL.com You are signed in as Edit Public Profile Sign Out Subscribe The Birmingham News The Huntsville Times Press-Register Email newsletters Text alerts Alabama Change Region Real-Time News from AL.com Here's the best grocery store in Alabama By  Leada Gore | lgore@al.com AL.com Email the author Follow on Twitter on September 16, 2016 at 6:01 AM, updated September 16, 2016 at 9:00 AM Print Email The best grocery store in Alabama has three locations in the state. (Contributed photo/Renfroe's Market) Is there anyone who really likes grocery shopping? Probably not. But your shopping experience can differ from store to store and as Daily Meal recently discovered, not all supermarkets are created equal. Daily Meal examined reviews on Google, Yelp, Foursquare and Facebook and analyzed social media posts and check-ins, as well as input from local residents, to determine the best grocery store in each state. Keep in mind, the best grocery store is different than the most popular one in each state, with the second having to do with concentration and number of locations. You can see Alabama's most popular grocery store here. If you're in search of the best grocery store in the state, you will want to look outside the major chains. According to Daily Meal, the state's top supermarket is Renfroe's Market. The locally owned grocery store has two locations in Montgomery and one in Dadeville. Here's how the Daily Meal described Renfroe's: "A longtime Montgomery institution, Renfroe's Market focuses on giving value to every customer's dollar. As one reviewer put it, "Kind of like Wal-Mart and Publix in 1. Layout and selection of Publix but prices like Wal-Mart! Great grocery store!" Welcome to Friday's Wake Up Call. Let's see what's going on today: $24k of fish stolen The city of Villa Rica, Georgia wants to know what happened to its fish. Someone stole $24,000 worth of city-owned koi fish that were at the Pine Mountain Gold Museum. A surveillance camera captured the image of three men that are suspected of being involved in the fish caper. The three men had fishing poles, officials said, and are believed to have made off with at least eight fish valued at $3,000 each. Giant meteorite uncovered One of the largest meteorites ever discovered has been unearthed in Argentina. Scientists said the meteorite, dubbed Gancedo, weighs about 30 tons. It's thought it smashed into the Earth more than 4,000 years ago. If all the tests check out, Gancedo would be the third largest meteorite ever found. The largest, unearthed in Africa, weighs in at 66 tons. Woman in infamous heroin photo jailed The Ohio grandmother whose image went viral after a photo of her and a friend passed out in a car from an apparent heroin overdose – all while her 4-year-old grandson was in the backseat – will spend the next 180 days in jail. Rhonda Pasek pleaded no contest to of endangering a child, public intoxication, and a seat belt violation. Court officials said she will be required to serve her full 180 day sentence. James Lee Acord, 47, who was arrested with Pasek, has also pleaded no contest and is serving a 360 day sentence for endangering a child and other charges. Pasek, 50, was arrested Sept. 7. She had been raising the 4-year-old boy, and his 3-year-old brother, because her son and his girlfriend were unable to care for the children. The boys have now been placed with their great aunt and uncle in South Carolina. Part of missing Malaysian plane found A large item of debris found off the coast of Tanzania is part of the missing Malaysia Airlines Fight MH370, officials said. The debris is part of the outboard flap of the plane. It was found in June but its source was just confirmed by Australian investigators. MH370 vanished in March 2014 as it flew from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing with 239 people on board, prompting a massive search. It's believed the plane crashed into the southern Indian Ocean. Until tomorrow. Updated: November 18, 2016 @ 7:53 am Full Forecast News Sports Opinion Events Obituaries Buy & Sell Close OTHER VIEW Other View: Income liftoff shows the recovery is real Sep 16, 2016 2 During the past two years, we have seen signs that wage pressure is building as the economic recovery grinds on. Enough evidence has now accumulated to suggest that it is already happening. The latest data, courtesy of the Census Bureau, which released its annual update on incomes and poverty on Tuesday, showed that median household income increased a whopping 5.2 percent in 2015 to an inflation-adjusted $56,516. As the New York Times, noted, it was “the largest single-year increase since record-keeping began in 1967.” Some killjoys will note that median household income was $57,909 in 1999. That’s true, but the dot-com crash, housing bust and the credit crisis managed to cut that a lot. Median incomes fell 2.59 percent from 2000 to 2004, before almost rebounding to the pre-crisis peak. After 2007, the collapse was greater — a 4.94 percent drop that bottomed in 2013. Ignore the naysayers; the most recent numbers were a huge positive surprise, showing that incomes for all Americans are rising in a meaningful way. Unlike in recent years, when much of the gains went to an increasingly narrow group at the top of the economic strata, last year’s improvements were broad and deep. “Gains were spread across the income spectrum and by race, while women’s earnings inched closer to men’s,” Bloomberg reported. This is yet more evidence of a job market that, as we previously noted, is not getting weaker but stronger — despite the occasional disappointing number. Of particular surprise to many was that the strongest gains were found among the lowest earners. To what shall we attribute these gains? Four things deserve most of the credit: More people working: The big year-over-year change in employment, with almost 2.5 million more Americans working now than a year earlier, contributed to a meaningful change in total household income. Corporate pay increases: Some of the U.S.’s largest employers, such as McDonald’s and Wal-Mart, have played a significant role in raising incomes at the lower end of the income distribution. Wal-Mart in particular made substantial increases in wages for its lowest-paid employees. These increases stand in sharp contrast to the company’s pay policies of just a few years ago. Note that the increases are not just a public-relations effort, but due to the competitive labor environment; higher pay is needed to recruit and retain workers (and because workers demoralized by the low pay and unappealing employment conditions were hurting the shopping experience for Wal-Mart customers). Minimum wage laws: Pay increases aren’t just voluntarily; after many years of little change in state and local minimum wage laws, increases mandated by legislation are kicking. That means the lowest-paid workers have seen pay rise in a number of cities and states. Economic cycle: We are now in the latter stages of an economic recovery. Typically, we see wage pressure and inflation at some point in the cycle, although usually much earlier than this. But this isn’t the typical postwar recovery — it is a recovery from a financial crisis. These rebounds are longer and slower than others, as excesses of the credit boom must be worked off. The deleveraging process takes a long time. The latest data is unequivocally good for households; what investors need to do is consider what this might mean more broadly. Rising incomes have ramifications for inflation, Federal Reserve policy, interest rates, retail spending, auto sales and residential real estate; it might even play a part in the presidential election. More than seven years have passed since the last bear market and the Great Recession ended. The recovery has been slow and fitful, and hasn’t always been very convincing for many Americans. This improvement was a long time coming. Greet it with open arms. Ritholtz, a Bloomberg View columnist, is the founder of Ritholtz Wealth Management. He is a consultant at and former chief executive officer for FusionIQ, a quantitative research firm. From 1p.m. - 2p.m. Central time. Combining the power of "knowing why and how" and understanding sound scientific principles with practice of active positive outcomes, the webinar focuses on the impact that leaders can have on employee behaviors that drive food safety. CEO of STOP Foodborne Illness Deirdre Schlunegger will be speaking, along with special guests Frank Yiannas, Walmart's Vice President of Food Safety; Michael Taylor, Freedman Consulting's Senior Fellow; and Steve Schluneger, Principal of Intrinsic Leadership. "A strong emphasis on food safety culture is emerging, and leadership is critical in creating and maintaining this culture," Yiannas says. In a world where businesses in the food industry are more aware of being susceptible to foodborne illnesses such as salmonella and the norovirus, the need for a strong food safety culture is more prevalent than ever before. The first line supervisors set the tone for the culture and behavior of employees, and our key note speakers explain how these business leaders can drive effective food safety practices. The program will be recorded. Registration is $129. Sign up today here. Please direct any questions about the webinar to klombardo@stopfoodborneillness.org. About STOP Foodborne Illness STOP Foodborne Illness is a national, nonprofit, public health organization dedicated to preventing illness and death from foodborne pathogens by advocating for sound public policies, building public awareness and assisting those impacted by foodborne illness. For more food safety tips please visit http://www.stopfoodborneillness.org/awareness/. If you think you have been sickened from food, check and contact your local health professional. For questions and personal assistance, please contact STOP Foodborne Illness' Community Coordinator, Stanley Rutledge, at srutledge@stopfoodborneillness.org or 773-269-6555 x7. # # # Read more Press Releases from Cindy Kurman: Nando'S PERi-PERi Hatches in Skokie and Oakbrook Nando's Peri-Peri Declares: Pick a Side on Election Day! 210 Restaurant & Live Music Lounge Rearranges Music Offerings to Bring You the Cubs' World Series Games Musical Lineup for November at 210 Restaurant & Live Music Lounge in Highwood Features Eclectic Mix of Exciting Rock, Soul, Funk and Jazz Artists 210 Restaurant and Live Music Lounge Focuses on Great Music AND Great Food Comment on this story... I'm not lazy, I'm agoraphobic. I used to spend my days at work, my nights in Manhattan, and my weekends filled with adventure and road trips. Now, if I am able to leave my house for a medical appointment, it’s an accomplishment.  I’ve had “episodes” that lasted months, where I’d be unable to leave my bed — not because I’m lazy, but out of fear. Tumblr I suffer from a very misunderstood disease called agoraphobia, which is the fear of open spaces (a very generalized definition). When I tell people, their first response is, “What? You’re afraid of spiders?” No, that would be arachnophobia. TheOdysseyOnline To be honest, I’m not even entirely sure of how I came to be this way, so I don’t judge those who don't understand. It started some time in 2013. It wasn’t a conscious decision; I just stopped leaving my home. My husband would ask if I wanted to go out, and my answer was always no. Neither one of us actually realized how long it had been since I’d left until a month or two in when my husband looked at me and said, “Wait. When was the last time you left?” and I couldn’t answer. Grocery stores were impossible (and still are), Target, Walmart, any store with more than one department is completely out of the question.  Imgur You may wonder how the hell I survive parenting without actually leaving the house? I’d be lying if I came up with any response other than, “I have no idea!” I take it day by day. I’m lucky enough to have a very supportive husband, who takes care of all the “outside” stuff I’m unable to. He brings my son to the park, does the food shopping, etc.  When I do go out, my husband HAS to be with me. I can’t go hang out with friends, or run to the store without him; to me, he’s like the security blanket little kids take EVERYWHERE. Tumblr Am I thrilled with how my life is? Not exactly, but every day, I work on it. I try and make trips to the store with my husband, though most of the time, I remain a passenger in the car and don’t actually venture into the store. I have gone to my son’s doctor appointments; basically, anything essential, I find a way to do it. Whether it’s taking an extra dose of anti-anxiety medicine (approved by my psychiatrist), or practicing breathing exercises to calm my nerves, I find a way. If you invite me to a picnic or BBQ at your house, it’s pretty much a given that I will not attend. All my friends know this and have already stopped inviting me, either to ease the pressure off me or just because, why bother? Tumblr So, what does it feel like when I’m forced outside of my comfort zone? It feels like I’m trapped in a tunnel, with every terrorist and mass murderer that has ever lived. Everyone is a suspect, not based on race or gender. I can see Big Bird and be suspicious and scared. My mind automatically goes into defense mode: Does this person have a gun? Does this person intend to carjack the vehicle I’m idling in? Will this be the next location of a mass shooting? Because you never think it’ll happen to you until it does, so I keep that in mind. I don’t care how safe or friendly your neighborhood is, it can happen anywhere.  When my husband and son go out, I worry it’s the last time I’ll see them. What if there’s an attack? All the “what ifs?” go through my brain at a pace I can hardly keep up with while I try to ignore it. Imgur And unfortunately, my brain can’t turn off that part of itself to allow me to enjoy outside activities like others do.  I can’t tell if I’m the product of the society we currently live in or if I would have been this way no matter what. All I know is that every time I make it past my front door, it’s a tiny victory in my life. And I know that one day, I’ll overcome this, because I want to live life outside of my comfort zone. I want to live life as a person who’s free from irrational fears. I want to show my son that despite the world we live in, and the scary things that happen daily, the world can be a pretty great place. 19 Quotes For When Anxiety Feels Completely Overwhelming Click to view (19 images) Photo: weheartit Rebecca Jane StokesEditor Buzz Read Later like us on facebook If you 'like' us, we'll LOVE you! Walmart Proponents to Present at Pittsfield Ward 1 & 2 Meeting By Andy McKeeveriBerkshires Staff 02:19AM / Friday, September 16, 2016Print | Email PITTSFIELD, Mass. — The developers looking to build a Walmart Supercenter at the William Stanley Business Park will present their plans at a meeting on Monday.   Waterstone Realty is proposing a new 190,000 square-foot super center on a parcel known as "the teens." Walmart would then vacate its currently location at Berkshire Crossing and would have its retail branch find a replacement for that building. The project has received a letter of intent from the Pittsfield Economic Development Authority to pursue permitting as well as negotiate a lease-to-own agreement for the land.   The company has not yet filed a formal proposal to city officials but the concept has been presented to the public at multiple forums and mediums since June. Ward 1 Councilor Lisa Tully and Ward 2 Councilor Kevin Morandi organized Monday's meeting to let residents hear the plans, ask questions, and start the dialogue over what has become a contentious issue.   "We just want to give the opportunity to the people, to let them know what this is about, and give us feedback," Morandi said on Thursday.   The presentation is put on by the two councilors, but anyone is welcomed to attend. Morandi says he hopes for a good attendance.    Representatives from the company will give a presentation at 6 p.m. at Morningside Community School. That will be followed by a question-and-answer session. The parcel in question borders Ward 1 and 2 and the councilors plan to hold three different public sessions throughout the process.    "We know how important this is as an issue so the more feedback, the more they can learn about the project, the better," Morandi said. "This is probably going to be a six-month process."   The issue has many aspects to it. Firstly, the land is formerly owned by General Electric and was passed to PEDA for development. PEDA has been working for years to find industrial suitors, which some say was the original intent of the park, but was unsuccessful. This is the third time Waterstone has attempted to develop the parcel into mixed-use and retail.    The company says it will be spending some $12 million on foundation work as part of the $30 million project. That work will address a stormwater system issue in which PCBs are still washing downstream and into Silver Lake. But, it will also include containing the PCBs in the soil. The foundational issues has been cited by city officials as being one of the major holdups to finding a developer.   Further the company is also looking to fix the intersection of Tyler Street, Woodlawn Avenue, and Dalton Avenue, which the city hoped to do with a federal grant, which it was not awarded. Lastly, the company says the development will help spur other companies to move onto the land near the Walmart.    It is estimated that the new project will boost tax revenue by some $300,000 to $500,000.   "Anytime someone wants to come in, it is the city's job to listen to them," Morandi said.   But many in opposition to the deal have raised concerns about Walmart's business practices and its impacts to nearby local businesses, and giving up for retail one of the few large spaces available for industry.    The issue also comes at a time when the city is in the middle of the Transformative Development Initiative, which is crafting a long-term vision for the future of the neighborhood.   Morandi says he hopes Monday's meeting will help set the groundwork for the community conversation around the project as it moves along.   Related Recent Walmart Stories: PEDA Extends Negotiation Period With Waterstone August 17, 2016 | 04:30PM The Pittsfield Economic Development Authority extended the timeframe to reach an land lease agreement with Waterstone Realty for the development of a Walmart Supercenter. On Tuesday, PEDA approved the extension to the letter of intent. Executive Director Corydon Thurston said the original 60-day window was "too aggressive" and hopes to have an agreement before the board by the next meeting. In 2013, the company closed the store it had been occupying for since 1993 and moved down the road to a former gravel bed. The gravel bed had been assessed at $1,613,800 and the redevelopment upped the value to $10,694,900, according to Ross Vivori, chairman of the North Adams Board of Assessors. City, state and Pittsffield Economic Development Agency officials commemorated the re-opening of the north to south connection between the Morningside Neighborhood and East Street. The bridge used to be own by General Electric and was closed in 2006 and was demolished in 2012. Pending EPA Permit Part of Waterstone Pitch For PEDA... June 27, 2016 | 01:53AM Part of the selling point for the new Walmart at the William Stanley Business Park is that it will ease an environmental burden on PEDA coming down the road. Last year, the Environmental Protection Agency issued a new draft permit for the Pittsfield Economic Development Agency's ability to drain stormwater into Silver Lake. That permit called for significantly better water quality than currently being done. He is considered a person of interest at this time. featured $5,000 reward for leads in pawn shop burglary By Tom Smith Senior Staff Writer Sep 16, 2016 0 Buy Now Russellville Police are trying to locate this man to talk with him about a fire and burglary of Mike's Pawn II that happened during the early morning hours of Sept. 3. He is considered a person of interest at this time. RUSSELLVILLE – A $5,000 reward is being offered in an effort to try and find out who is responsible for the burglary of a Russellville pawn shop and theft of a large number of guns. According to information from Michael Knight of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, the burglary took place during the early morning hours of Sept. 3 at Mike’s Pawn II. Police Chief Chris Hargett said the business is located on U.S. 43 just past Wal-Mart, near Akins Funeral Home. Authorities said around 60 guns were taken from the business. “After they took the guns, the building was set on fire,” said investigator Sgt. Jake Tompkins. Reports indicate the building was destroyed by the fire. Tompkins said the fire was intentionally set. “Evidence was found that indicated that the fire was arson,” Tompkins said. Knight said ATF is offering a $2,500 reward, which will be matched by the National Shooting Sports Foundation for a total reward of up to $5,000. Officials said the reward is part of a cooperative initiative between the NSSF and ATF in cases involving the theft of firearms from federally licensed firearms retailers. Tompkins said police are looking for a man who is considered to be a person of interest. “Not a suspect, but a person of interest,” Tompkins said. “We would love to talk with this person to see what he knows about the burglary.” Tompkins said the burglary was reported to authorities at 3:46 a.m. He said the burglars got into the business by damaging a back wall. ATF officials said investigators are in the process of conducting an inventory to determine the exact number of guns taken. Anyone with information about the burglary and arson is asked to contact the ATF at 800-ATF-GUNS (1-800-283-4867), the Russellville Police Department at 256-332-2230, or Shoals Crime Stoppers at 256-386-8685. Information can also be sent to ATF via the mobile app www.reportit.com by using the Nashville Field Division as the location. The Russellville Police Department, ATF and the Alabama State Fire Marshal’s office are involved in the investigation. tom.smith@timesdaily.com or 256-740-5757. Life Buy/Sell Letters to the editor Close Buy Now David Carson Morning traffic traveling on Missouri Route 141 ( pictured from the bottom of the photo to the top) passes under Highway 40 (Interstate 64) as seen on Tuesday, May 7, 2013. Photo By David Carson, dcarson@post-dispatch.com Drivers keep butting in line on Highway 141 Sep 16, 2016 (…) Buy Now David Carson Morning traffic traveling on Missouri Route 141 ( pictured from the bottom of the photo to the top) passes under Highway 40 (Interstate 64) as seen on Tuesday, May 7, 2013. Photo By David Carson, dcarson@post-dispatch.com Would you go to a Cardinals game, see a long line of people waiting to enter Busch Stadium, walk to the front of the line and cut in ahead of those waiting? Would you go to Walmart with its long lines and cut in front of the people waiting? I hope the answer in both examples is no. If that is true, then why do so many people think it is OK for them to bypass the line of cars on northbound Highway 141 to cut in at the last second to take the exit for the Page Avenue Extension? As a commuter who travels this road each day, I have been horrified to see the accidents, near-accidents and intense road rage caused by these people. In case you have not realized it, you are telling all of us who are waiting in line that you consider your life to be much more important than anyone else’s. Because you are in a car, you somehow feel that you are not seen by others. Guess what: You are wrong. Everyone in that line can see who you are. So, the next time you are asking for help for your child at school, that teacher you are talking with may have been the driver you cut off the night before. The next time you are at the emergency room pleading for help, that nurse may have been the driver who you forced off the road when you almost slammed into her yesterday. Until people grow up or the local municipalities decide to add a double white line to separate traffic (as was done on Interstate 270 northbound at Interstate 70), this will continue to be a very dangerous section of road every night. I pray that happens before there are more accidents or that road rage escalates to a dangerous point. I ask that all of us take a second to think about others before we drive past a mile-long line of cars and dart in just in time to take the exit. Steve Starr  •  O'Fallon, Mo. Getting from A to B without a vehicle is difficult in Victoria, said Corpus Christi resident Teresa Longoria. "I do find it kind of crazy how they don't have too many lights out there," said Longoria, 26. Thursday, Longoria, who was struck by a car Wednesday night, rested in a room at Citizens Medical Center, recovering from a concussion, road rash and a torn ligament in her leg. Longoria, who is 19 weeks pregnant with a girl she will name Jae'La, was struck by a blue Honda Civic before 10 p.m. Wednesday on Houston Highway just outside Motel 6, where she was staying. The driver of the Civic, Melissa Longoria, no relation, was uninjured and not cited, said Victoria police Sgt. Lee Lemmons. Teresa Longoria was attempting to walk to Wal-Mart, which was less than 2,000 feet from her motel room - a trip she has made multiple times in the past. "I went flying and went over the car and hit the back side," Longoria said. "I rolled off and (then) landed on my right side." Despite the severity of the impact, Longoria said she and her unborn baby are OK, albeit a little sore. Longoria was talking on the phone with Jae'La's father, 24-year-old Kristopher Durst, of Victoria, when she was struck. "It scared him because all he heard was me saying, 'Ow!'" she said. Longoria admits she could have used a crosswalk at Sam Houston Drive to cross Houston Highway. But because she has never had problems crossing in Corpus Christi or Victoria until Wednesday, she felt confident walking across Houston Highway without a crosswalk. Although she may be physically all right, Longoria said her perception of Victoria is not. A lack of pedestrian amenities has in part convinced her she does not want move to Victoria, she said. "The city could do better with lights and crosswalks," she said. "I noticed there are not too many sidewalks out here." Suburbs Aurora Beacon-News Aurora News School comes together to raise money for 9-year-old's rare cancer treatment Juan and Carlos Romero Sarah Freishtat / The Beacon-News Juan Romero, right, is looking to raise money to help with a type of cancer treatment for his son, Carlos. Juan Romero, right, is looking to raise money to help with a type of cancer treatment for his son, Carlos. (Sarah Freishtat / The Beacon-News) Sarah FreishtatAurora Beacon-News Privacy Policy Carlos Romero likes playing video games and going to Taco Bell with his dad, activities he described as "typical boy things." The 9-year-old Aurora boy used to play piano and take karate lessons, until he was diagnosed when he was 7 with osteosarcoma, a type of bone cancer. His father, Juan Romero, said Carlos didn't need to worry about the extra activities through chemotherapy treatments, leg surgery and three lung surgeries he underwent to combat tumors that kept coming back. After years of treatments, Romero, is now looking to a drug that has not been approved in the U.S., but is used in Europe, to keep his son's cancer at bay. The treatment will cost tens-of-thousands of dollars that Romero will have to pay up front, a spokeswoman for Chicago's Ann and Robert H. Lurie Children's Hospital said, so Carlos' West Aurora elementary school has organized fundraisers to help. Romero is an involved McCleery Elementary School parent, Principal Kathy Kostos said. Romero said he drops off Carlos and his younger sister in the morning, stops by during the day to drop off medicine for Carlos and then picks up his children, before going to Wal-Mart to work his 5:30 to 11 p.m. shift. "(Carlos is) one of our students," Kostos said. "And we want to do what we can to try and help him out. It's important to us to help any of our kids." Carlos was, at first, diagnosed with a tumor in his leg. He had surgery to remove it, had a metal rod put into his leg, and had to learn to walk again — a process Carlos compared to beating all of the levels on a video game, only to have the game accidentally uninstalled and having to work through each level again. He spent a year in and out of the hospital, one week in for treatment, two weeks home, Romero said. Through his treatments, he completed his schoolwork and stayed on pace. Girl's 'courage' during cancer treatment brings Aurora school together Linda Girardi Ailani Banuelos received a celebrity welcome with a stream of yellow balloons when she arrived at McCarty Elementary School in Aurora. The surprise welcome for the 10-year-old McCarty student, complete with T-shirts in Ailani's favorite blue and the release of 25 white doves, celebrated her final... Ailani Banuelos received a celebrity welcome with a stream of yellow balloons when she arrived at McCarty Elementary School in Aurora. The surprise welcome for the 10-year-old McCarty student, complete with T-shirts in Ailani's favorite blue and the release of 25 white doves, celebrated her final... (Linda Girardi) His family thought he was cured, until they found cancer in his lung in August 2015. Romero said he traveled across the country seeking information and treatment for Carlos. Carlos ultimately had three lung surgeries to remove tumors that kept coming back. During the latest surgery, shortly before the start of the 2016 school year, doctors removed part of his lung. Romero said the family has tried to avoid words like "tumor" and "cancer." If a commercial for a children's cancer hospital comes on TV, they change the channel. Carlos doesn't know he's missing part of his lung, and refers to his cancer in past tense, Romero said. He said Carlos is smart and happy. "Why I've got to give to him worries, in his mind, that he may die?" he said. Now, Romero is looking to a drug called Mepact for Carlos. Though not approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, it is used in other countries, said Julie Pesch, a spokeswoman for Lurie Children's Hospital. Cancer survivor inspires others David Sharos Aurora resident Sylvia Forsberg, who defied doctors' expectations in beating cancer — twice — and inspired a host of people along the way, was honored by Rush-Copley Medical Center as part of a national day of recognition for those reaching milestones in their fight against the disease. "I've lived... Aurora resident Sylvia Forsberg, who defied doctors' expectations in beating cancer — twice — and inspired a host of people along the way, was honored by Rush-Copley Medical Center as part of a national day of recognition for those reaching milestones in their fight against the disease. "I've lived... (David Sharos) Romero said he talked with a U.S. doctor and "so many people in different countries" about the medication. He said he sought help from local elected officials to be able to use the drug in this country. "That's all what we have for him," Romero said. "We don't have more medicine to cure this cancer." Pesch said the drug was studied in the U.S. in the 1990s, but the results were conflicting and it ultimately was not approved by the FDA. Carlos will need two, $24,000 dosages of the medication over a six-month time frame, Pesch said. Since the family is not able to use the medicine under the "compassionate use" designation — which typically refers to the treatment of someone who is seriously ill using an unapproved drug, if no other treatments are available — and because it is not FDA-approved, Carlos' family will have to pay the cost up front to the drug company, Pesch said. "It's laudable, what this father and family are doing, to try this," said Kathleen Keenan, another Lurie spokeswoman. "If the hospital thought there were zero possibility and it were worthless, we'd never be on board with it." McCleery elementary school is looking to help with the expense. Assistant Principal Jalitza Martinez helped organize an exercise event last Saturday, with area instructors and special guests leading exercise classes and workouts. A local recording artist was set to sing during Zumba class, she said. School staff is also helping organize a fundraiser Sept. 22 at Luigi's Pizza and Fun Center on Aurora's near West Side, with all-you-can-east pizza and pasta and raffle prizes. "Right away, our staff wanted to do something and help in any way they could," Kostos, the principal, said. Kostos said it took some convincing before Romero was willing to let the school help. Kostos said the school helped him set up a GoFundMe page for Carlos in February. Now, he is seeking to raise $100,000 for Carlos' treatment. Kostos said Carlos is a "motivated learner." His dad took him to the library to check out books over the summer, and the school gave him books to read while he was in the hospital, she said. Carlos has tried to come to school as long as he feels well enough, though some days he goes home early and some days he misses school entirely, Kostos said. Still, his attendance overall has been good, she said. Before Carlos was diagnosed with cancer, he would study multiplication and fractions with his dad outside of school. He wasn't allowed to play video games. Now, Carlos is allowed to play in moderation, Romero said. He doesn't want to push Carlos unnecessarily. Carlos said he is planning to be a teacher. He wants two kids, and he wants them to be smart, to grow up and have their own families. "I've been really looking forward to growing up and being a good father," he said. sfreishtat@tribpub.com Twitter @srfreish Copyright © 2016, Aurora Beacon-News Drugs and Medicines State's attorney says stiff Aurora murder sentence sends message Oswego considers decriminalizing marijuana School in Aurora named second best in the nation Breaking Sports Trending Opinion Suburbs Entertainment Business Advertising 61°

Father and son ID'd as victim and gunman in shooting that wounded Fort Worth officers Filed under Crime at Sep 17 Share Facebook Twitter Email Print This Story Written by Claire Ballor Claire Z. Cardona Get Daily Dallas News Headlines Sign Up Don't miss a story. Like us on Facebook. Like Dallas News' Facebook Page Get Unlimited Digital Access Your first month is less than a dollar. $0.99 for first 4 weeks Subscribe Now The man who wounded two Fort Worth police officers Friday night had a history of run-ins with the law and drug use, according to neighbors and court records. Police have not identified the gunman and his father, who was found dead at the scene, but the Tarrant County medical examiner's office confirmed Martin Craig Fleece, 55, and Carl Fleece, 81, were the two men fatally shot in the 3800 block of Wharton Drive, according to the Fort Worth Star-Telegram.  Martin Craig Fleece Hood County Sheriff's Office After officers were called to the home about 8:30 p.m. Friday, they found Carl Fleece dead inside the home with a gunshot wound to his head.  Although a report of a suicide brought them to the home, police have not said who fired the shot. Officers were told a witness to the shooting had gone to a shed in the backyard. When they approached the shed, Craig Fleece opened fire, police said. Fort Worth Officers Xavier Serrano and Ray Azucena were struck by bullets but are expected to survive. Fort Worth Police Chief Joel Fitzgerald said in a statement released Saturday, "[the officers'] prognosis is very good and they are both expected to make a full recovery from their wounds and a return to their job of protecting and serving our citizens." We appreciate everyone's thoughts and prayers, FWPD Officers Serrano (left) and Azucena (right) are recovering well. pic.twitter.com/L6pFF356yp— Fort Worth Police (@fortworthpd) September 17, 2016 Hours after Craig Fleece shot at the officers, SWAT team members were able to approach the shed, where they found him dead with multiple gunshot wounds. It is not known whether those wounds were self-inflicted or from police gunfire. Family tensions A neighbor told the Star-Telegram there seemed to be recurring problems with Craig Fleece. Carl Fleece and his wife, Vaneda, lived in the home and their son stayed in the backyard shed for most of the last 20 years, the neighbor said. Carl was a retired lieutenant colonel in the Air Force and a decorated B-52 pilot who was known for his kindness. Carl Fleece was a retired lieutenant colonel in the Air Force and a decorated B-52 pilot. Fort Worth Star-Telegram "They are wonderful, wonderful people," the neighbor told the Star-Telegram. "Very soft-spoken, never poked their noses in other people's business, kept to themselves." But the topic of the son, he said, seemed to be a sore spot. "They didn't talk much about him, but they did mention they were having a difficult time with him," Ron said. "Every time it got brought up ... [Carl Fleece] would get upset about it." Another neighbor, Jesse Guadina, said the police had been at the Fleeces' home at least six times during the last three years because of their son.  "If he wasn't causing trouble to his parents, he was causing trouble to his brother," Guadina said. Troubled past Craig Fleece had a past fraught with criminal and manic behavior. In 1998, he was accused of trying to kill a man in Louisiana. The charge was pleaded down to attempted manslaughter, and he was ordered to serve six months in prison and five years probation. While on probation in 2004 for the Louisiana incident, Fleece stole an ambulance in Fort Worth and made purchases with a debit card he found inside. He told police he got into the ambulance to get warm and drove off when looks from passers-by made him uncomfortable.  He stopped at a Wal-Mart, where he used the debit card to buy cleaning supplies to clean the ambulance, he told police. Fleece said he had planned to drive the ambulance to a friend's house in Lancaster where he could clean it up, but decided to drive it back to Fort Worth and ran out of gas. A psychologist testified that Craig Fleece, who suffered from bipolar disorder and appeared to be in the middle of a manic episode when he stole the ambulance, thought he might get a job if he cleaned the vehicle.  The court decided the testimony was irrelevant, and Fleece was sentenced to three years for debit card abuse and unauthorized use of a motor vehicle. Staff writer Claire Z. Cardona contributed to this report. Contests e-Edition Obits 2° Rain Home Our Team Contact Us Advertising Info News BC News Sports BC Sports BC Games NFL Business BC Business Entertainment BC Arts & Entertainment Community Calendar Submit an Event Lifestyles BC Lifestyles Tourism Info Opinion BC Opinions Letters Web Poll N2K World Canada / World Sports Vancouver Impress   Place Classified Ad Browse Classifieds BC Jobs Connect with Us     Opinion Editorial: An overpass would help our divided city TWO people have been killed in five days while attempting to cross through CN's Terrace, B.C. rail yard. — image credit: STAFF PHOTO     Terrace, B.C. posted Sep 17, 2016 at 1:00 PM The prospect of building a pedestrian overpass above CN’s rail yard which runs through the middle of the city is much stronger when viewed as more than a method to reduce trespassing over the tracks. Proper fencing with regular maintenance to repair any holes cut by trespassers will largely take care of access to the rail yard. But in the far broader picture an overpass should be  considered as a needed method of foot and cyclist transit to better connect what is now a divided city. Save for the sidewalks of the Sande Overpass, at the far western end of the rail yard, and constituting a significant  journey for those on foot or on a bike, there is now no access between the southside and the northside of the city for the long stretch from the Sande Overpass to the area of Walmart. It’s a significant omission for southside residents who deserve the opportunity of access to the majority of the city’s recreational, shopping and other services on the northside. Consider the large amount of social and low income housing on the southside in the area east of Mills Memorial Hospital to near Walmart – which could soon be bolstered should a Ksan House Society apartment building be constructed in that neighbourhood – and the need for a pedestrian and cyclist overpass is even more obvious. Of all the needs facing the city, this is one of the more doable. Politics Smart Living Money Entertainment Health Tech Science Sports Video Contests Live Like Follow Canada September 17, 2016 4:47 pm Pop-up food market opens in Halifax community By Natasha Pace Reporter  Global News ; A pop up market has recently started in Halifax. Natasha Pace/Global News What is this? Sponsored content is written by Global News' editorial staff without any editorial influence by the sponsor. If you'd like to learn more... What is this ? X What is this? Sponsored content is written by Global News' without any editorial influence by the sponsor. If you'd like to learn more... - A A + Listen There’s a new venture underway by one Halifax community to try and help address food insecurity. The Bayers Westwood Community Centre recently launched a pop-up food market. The neighbourhood is home to the largest public housing area in the city and organizers say many of the residents use the food bank. Donna Sutton Lahmar, director of the centre, says because of this, access to fresh fruit and vegetables is limited. “We as a centre thought it was really important to bring this service to the community, which everyone can just tap into,” said Lahmar. WATCH: Halifax ranked lowest city in Canada for food affordability  Lahmar says the group community centre purchases the food at cost from a local vender and also sells every item at cost. All of the vegetables and fruit at the market are under $2. “It’s actually cheaper than Superstore. Some things are a little cheaper than Walmart, but for the most part things are cheaper than the Superstore,” she said. Organizers decided to start the market as a way to help provide the community with access to fresh food #Halifax pic.twitter.com/3KsCbJORjv — Natasha Pace (@NatashaPace) September 17, 2016 Many volunteers at the pop-up market are members of the Syrian community who recently arrived in Halifax. This is the sixth weekend the market has been held, with it selling out of food every time. Lahmar says the idea is part of a pilot project that will run until the end of October and then restart in May. Follow @NatashaPace © 2016 Global News, a division of Corus Entertainment Inc. Court news: Teen requests speedy trial on 12 charges Mike Emery , mwemery@pal-item.com 4:49 p.m. EDT September 17, 2016 Rodney W. Blevins II (Photo: Supplied) 9 CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE One of three Richmond residents arrested for an August weekend crime spree has exercised his right to a speedy trial. Rodney W. Blevins II, 19, of the 1500 block of South 11th Street requested the speedy trial during a Sept. 2 initial hearing in Wayne Superior Court II. His trial was scheduled for 9 a.m. Oct. 3. Blevins was formally charged with 10 felonies and two misdemeanors after his Aug. 29 arrest along with Zachary T. Peacock and Ashley N. Sparks. He is charged with three counts of burglary (a Level 2 and two Level 4 felonies), four counts of conspiracy to commit burglary (a Level 2 and three Level 4 felonies), conspiracy to commit armed robbery (a Level 3 felony), attempt to commit burglary (a Level 4 felony), robbery (a Level 5 felony) and two counts of theft (both Class A misdemeanors). Blevins, Peacock and Sparks were arrested after police responded to a domestic dispute call. During the investigation, officers came across a gun they were told was stolen during a home burglary then was used in a series of crimes. Most of the crimes allegedly occurred from Aug. 26-Aug. 28. Because he was wanted for allegedly violating terms of a pretrial drug diversion program, Blevins has remained in the Wayne County Jail since his arrest. He faces charges of fraud (a Level 6 felony) and theft (a Class A misdemeanor) in that case, which is scheduled for an Oct. 24 trial. Peacock and Sparks were released on their own recognizance when the court didn't receive formal charges within 48 hours of their arrests, but they were arrested again Sept. 1 during RPD's investigation of a possible robbery in the 1200 block of Ridge Street. Zachary T. Peacock  (Photo: Supplied) Peacock, 20, of the 3800 block of Endsley Road now faces the same 12 charges as Blevins in one case and is charged with Level 6 felony attempt to commit residential entry in the second case. Peacock, who remains in the jail, also faces a probation violation following his release this year from prison after he served a seven-year sentence for armed robbery and burglary for using a handgun to rob the Clark station at 100 Richmond Ave. in 2013. Both new cases and the petition to revoke probation are scheduled for trial on Dec. 6 in Wayne Circuit Court, Ashley N. Sparks  (Photo: Supplied) Sparks, 25, of the 500 block of South West 16th Street faces four counts of aiding or inducing burglary (a Level 2 and three Level 4 felonies), four counts of conspiracy to commit burglary (a Level 2 and three Level 4 felonies), aiding or inducing armed robbery (a Level 3 felony), conspiracy to commit armed robbery (a Level 3 felony) and two counts of aiding or inducing theft (Class A misdemeanors). In her second case, Sparks, who remains jailed, is charged with Level 5 felony intimidation and Level 6 felony attempt to commit residential entry. A trial on the second case is scheduled for Nov. 28 in Superior II, but no trial has been scheduled for the first case, according to court records. Liberty man's trial set for Nov. 29 A Liberty man's trial in two cases has been scheduled for Nov. 29 in Circuit Court. James Goubeaux, 32, of the 400 block of North Woodland Court was arrested Aug. 28 after a nearly nine-hour manhunt. James Goubeaux  (Photo: Supplied) The hunt began after the alleged use of a stolen credit card at Richmond's Wal-Mart and continued with two burglary incidents. He was captured after he told good Samaritans helping him that he was lost, and they asked officers to help him find his way. He was formally charged with theft and attempted fraud (both Level 6 felonies) in one case and with two counts of burglary (Level 4 felonies) in the second case. He also is accused of being a habitual offender in the second case. Goubeaux, who remains jailed, also has a plea and sentencing hearing set for 2:30 p.m. Oct. 24 in Randolph County on charges of conversion and driving while suspended (both Class A misdemeanors). A woman who tried to use a stolen credit card at Wal-Mart was caught on foot on nearby Avon Lane as Goubeaux began eluding police. Ashley R. Reed  (Photo: Supplied) Ashley R. Reed, 33, of the 1500 block of South Ninth Street in Richmond is formally charged with attempt to commit fraud and two counts of theft (all Level 6 felonies). In a previous case, she is charged with theft and unlawful possession of a syringe (both Level 6 felonies). Her trials also are scheduled for Nov. 29 in Circuit Court. 9 CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE Read or Share this story: http://pinews.co/2cuzhGS TOP VIDEOS Ben Sullivan signs with West Point 1:10 Hollingsworth signs with IUPUI Tennis 0:55 Richmond boys basketball prepares for 2016-17 2:03 Knights sign for college programs 0:52 Hagerstown wins volleyball regional 1:37 Officer Tim Davis teaches Halloween safety lessons 3:34 RPD investigates North 15th shooting 1:24 Richmond qualifies for state tennis 2:34 Indiana 1 accident injures both drivers Oct. 3, 2016 0:54 Centerville celebrates huge victory 0:32 More Stories Wayne County residents wonder what's to come for Obamacare Nov. 17, 2016, 7:27 p.m. Educators look for usable data in ISTEP scores Nov. 17, 2016, 5:31 p.m. Chase nets 1 suspect near Abington; 1 gets away Nov. 17, 2016, 4:31 p.m. Go: Electric violin, comedy, crafts and more Nov. 16, 2016, 8:27 p.m.

StyleCaster StyleCaster Fashion Beauty Lifestyle Entertainment SCtv Shop StyleCaster StyleCaster StyleCaster Fashion Beauty Lifestyle Entertainment SCtv Shop StyleCaster StyleCaster Share Facebook Pinterest Twitter Tumblr The Best Full-Coverage Foundations That Won’t Make You Look Cakey What's hot IMPORTANT: Khloe Kardashian Got a Short, White-Blonde... Khloé Kardashian Got Her First Wax in Sixth Grade The Best Beauty Products to Scoop Up at Walmart 30 Simple Holiday Makeup Ideas to Copy Right Now Jenna Dewan-Tatum Got an Insanely Sleek, Blunt Lob StyleCaster The Best Full-Coverage Foundations That Won’t Make You Look Cakey Facebook Pinterest Twitter Tumblr 0 byLauren Caruso 412 Shares 2 months ago 13 Start slideshow Photo: Imaxtree You may have spent all summer trying to keep your makeup routine fairly minimal—that is, if you’ve already been blessed with flawless, poreless skin that just needs a swipe of BB cream to look Instagram-levels of perfect. But what about the rest of us with acne scars, hyperpigmentation, and all that fun redness that crops up around our nose? We crave a bit more coverage, and there’s no shame in that. MORE: The 7 Best Under-Eye Concealers, According to the Internet Still, foundation has a bad wrap for looking cakey, ghostly, or worse: like you’re trying too hard. Oftentimes, it can settle into fine lines or transfer to clothes, and if your makeup’s just sitting on your face and clogging your pores, you’re stuck in a seriously grim cycle of breakout, cover-up, rinse, and repeat. Luckily, there are a few formulas that can seamlessly blur imperfections while leaving you glowy—not cakey. Ahead, the 13 best full coverage foundations to try now.
